revision.text:
{{Year nav topic5|1615|music}}
== Events == *April – After a few months' employment at the court of the Duke of [[Mantua]], [[Ferdinando I Gonzaga]], [[Girolamo Frescobaldi]] returns to Rome.<ref>Hammond, Frederick. ''Girolamo Frescobaldi''.47, 54.</ref>
== Publications == *[[Girolamo Frescobaldi]] – ''Primo libro di toccate'' and ''Libro di recercari et canzoni'' *[[Giovanni Gabrieli]] – ''Symphoniae Sacrae'', Book 2, published posthumously *[[Hans Leo Hassler]] – ''Venusgarten'', a collection of instrumental music, published in [[Nuremberg]]
== Classical music == *[[Alessandro Grandi]] – ''Plorabo die ac nocte'', a motet for four voices
== Opera == *[[Francesca Caccini]] – ''Il ballo delle zigane'' (lost) *[[Claudio Monteverdi]] – Second edition of ''[[L'Orfeo]]''
== Births == *[[September 16]] – [[Heinrich Bach]], German organist (died 1692) *''date unknown'' **[[Giovanni Faustini]], librettist and opera impresario (died 1651) **[[Christopher Gibbons]], organist and composer (died 1676) *''probable'' – [[Francesca Campana]], singer, spinet player and composer (died 1665)
== Deaths == *[[June 15]] – [[Innocentio Alberti]], Italian cornet player and composer (born c. 1535) *[[August 7]] – [[Melchior Vulpius]], German composer, primarily of sacred music (born c.1570) *[[November 24]] – [[Sethus Calvisius]], music theorist, composer and astronomer (born 1556)
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:1615|Music]] [[Category:17th century in music]] [[Category:Years in music]]

[[File:Hadrians Wall map.svg|thumb|upright=1.25|alt=map of the UK with Antonine wall and Hadrian's wall|Location of the Antonine Wall and [[Hadrian's Wall]] in [[Scotland]] and [[Northern England]]]] {{RomanMilitary}}
The '''Antonine Wall''', known to the Romans as ''Vallum Antonini'', was a [[sod|turf]] [[fortification]] on stone foundations, built by the [[Ancient Rome|Romans]] across what is now the [[Central Belt]] of [[Scotland]], between the [[Firth of Forth]] and the [[Firth of Clyde]]. Representing the northernmost frontier barrier of the [[Roman Empire]], it spanned approximately {{convert|63|km|0|abbr=off}} and was about {{convert|3|m|0|abbr=off}} high and {{convert|5|m|0|abbr=off}} wide. [[Lidar]] scans have been carried out to establish the length of the wall and the Roman distance units used.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Krakowka|first1=Kathryn|title=Meticulous metric survey of the Antonine Wall|url=https://www.archaeology.co.uk/articles/meticulous-metric-survey-of-the-antonine-wall.htm|website=Current Archaeology|accessdate=28 April 2018|date=2018-04-24}}</ref> Security was bolstered by a deep [[ditch]] on the northern side. It is thought that there was a wooden [[palisade]] on top of the turf. The barrier was the second of two "great walls" created by the Romans in what the English once called [[Northern Britain]]. Its ruins are less evident than the better-known [[Hadrian's Wall]] to the south, primarily because the turf and wood wall has largely weathered away, unlike its stone-built southern predecessor.
Construction began in AD 142 at the order of [[Roman Emperor]] [[Antoninus Pius]], and took about 12 years to complete. Antoninus Pius never visited Britain, whereas his predecessor [[Hadrian]] did. Pressure from the [[Caledonians]] may have led Antoninus to send the empire's troops further north. The Antonine Wall was protected by 16 forts with small fortlets between them; troop movement was facilitated by a road linking all the sites known as the Military Way. The soldiers who built the wall commemorated the construction and their struggles with the Caledonians in decorative slabs, twenty of which survive. The wall was abandoned only eight years after completion, and the garrisons relocated back to Hadrian's Wall. In 208 Emperor [[Septimius Severus]] re-established legions at the wall and ordered repairs; this has led to the wall being referred to as the [[Wall of Severus|Severan Wall]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Elliott|first1=Simon|last2=Hughes|first2=Tristan|title=The Scottish Campaigns of Septimius Severus|url=http://turningpointsoftheancientworld.com/index.php/2018/03/18/scottish-campaigns-septimius-severus/|accessdate=21 May 2018|agency=Turning Points Of The Ancient World|date=18 March 2018}}</ref> The occupation ended a few years later, and the wall was never fortified again. Most of the wall and its associated fortifications have been destroyed over time, but some remains are visible. Many of these have come under the care of [[Historic Scotland]] and the [[UNESCO]] [[World Heritage Committee]].<ref>{{cite web|title=The Antonine Wall Management Plan 2014-19|url=http://www.antoninewall.org/system/files/documents/494733_283836_Antonine_Wall_MP_WEB_20131125134011.pdf#page=7|website=Antonine Wall|accessdate=28 April 2018}}</ref>
{{clear|left}} __TOC__ [[File:Antoninus Wall near Bar Hill.jpg|thumb|400px|Wall near Bar Hill showing ditch]]
==Location and construction== [[File:Antonine Wall - geograph.org.uk - 49196.jpg|thumb|300px|Stone foundation of the Wall in Bearsden]]
[[Roman Emperor]] [[Antoninus Pius]] ordered the construction of the Antonine Wall around 142.<ref>Robertson, Anne S. (1960) ''The Antonine Wall''. Glasgow Archaeological Society. p. 7.</ref> [[Quintus Lollius Urbicus]], governor of [[Roman Britain]] at the time, initially supervised the effort, which took about twelve years to complete.<ref>Breeze, David J. (2006) ''The Antonine Wall''. Edinburgh. John Donald. {{ISBN|0-85976-655-1}} p. 167.</ref> The wall stretches {{convert|63|km|0|abbr=off}} from [[Old Kilpatrick]] in [[West Dunbartonshire]] on the [[Firth of Clyde]] to [[Carriden House|Carriden]] near [[Bo'ness]] on the [[Firth of Forth]]. The wall was intended to extend Roman territory and dominance by replacing [[Hadrian's Wall]] {{convert|160|km|0|abbr=off}} to the south, as the frontier of ''[[Roman Britain|Britannia]]''. But while the Romans did establish many forts and temporary camps further north of the Antonine Wall in order to protect their routes to the north of Scotland, they did not conquer the [[Caledonians]], and the Antonine Wall suffered many attacks. The Romans called the land north of the wall ''[[Caledonia (Roman)|Caledonia]]'', though in some contexts the term may refer to the whole area north of Hadrian's Wall.
The Antonine Wall was shorter than Hadrian's Wall and built of [[Sod|turf]] on a stone foundation, but it was still an impressive achievement. The stone foundations and wing walls of the original forts demonstrate that the original plan was to build a stone wall similar to Hadrian's Wall, but this was quickly amended. As built, the wall was typically a bank, about four metres (13 feet) high, made of layered turves and occasionally earth with a wide [[ditch (fortification)|ditch]] on the north side, and a [[Roman road|military way]] on the south. The Romans initially planned to build forts every {{convert|10|km|0|abbr=off}}, but this was soon revised to every {{convert|3.3|km|0|abbr=off}}, resulting in a total of nineteen forts along the wall. The best preserved but also one of the smallest forts is [[Rough Castle Fort]]. In addition to the forts, there are at least 9 smaller fortlets, very likely on Roman mile spacings, which formed part of the original scheme, some of which were later replaced by forts.<ref name="L.Keppie, Scotland's Roman Remains 1986">L.Keppie, Scotland's Roman Remains. Edinburgh 1986)</ref> The most visible fortlet is Kinneil, at the eastern end of the Wall, near Bo'ness.<ref>[http://www.historic-scotland.gov.uk/index/policyandguidance/world_heritage_scotland/antoninewall.htm Historic Scotland - Looking after our heritage - The Antonine Wall<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
There was once a remarkable Roman structure within sight of the Antonine Wall at [[Stenhousemuir]]. This was [[Arthur's O'on]], a circular stone domed monument or [[Rotunda (architecture)|rotunda]], which may have been a temple, or a [[Tropaion|''tropaeum'']], a victory monument. It was demolished for its stone in 1743, though a replica exists at [[Penicuik House]]. [[File:Antonine.Wall.Roman.forts.jpg|thumb|upright=4|center|alt=map of Antonine wall with forts|Forts and ''Fortlets''<ref>{{cite web|last1=Hunter|first1=Fraser|last2=Carruthers|first2=Martin|title=ScARF Summary Roman Presence Report|url=http://www.scottishheritagehub.com/sites/default/files/u12/ScARF%20Roman%20June%202012.pdf#page=26|website=Scottish Heritage Hub|accessdate=28 April 2018}}</ref> associated with the Antonine Wall<ref>{{cite web|last1=Kent|first1=Emerson|title=Alternative Map of the Wall|url=http://www.emersonkent.com/map_archive/antonine_wall_142.htm|accessdate=7 May 2018}}</ref> from west to east: [[Bishopton, Renfrewshire|Bishopton]], [[Old Kilpatrick]], [[Duntocher]], ''[[Cleddans]]'', [[Castlehill Fort|Castlehill]], [[Bearsden]], ''[[Summerston]]'', [[Balmuildy]], ''[[Wilderness Plantation]]'', [[Cadder]], ''[[Glasgow Bridge, Kirkintilloch|Glasgow Bridge]]'', [[Kirkintilloch]], [[Auchendavy]], [[Bar Hill Fort|Bar Hill]], [[Croy Hill]], [[Westerwood]], [[Castlecary]], ''[[Seabegs Wood|Seabegs]]'', [[Rough Castle]], [[Camelon]], ''[[Watling Lodge]]'', [[Falkirk]], [[Mumrills]], [[Inveravon]], ''[[Kinneil House|Kinneil]]'', [[Carriden House|Carriden]]]] [[File:Romanwallinscotl00macduoft raw 0197.jpg|thumb|450px|[[The Bridgeness Slab]] - The easternmost distance slab]]
In addition to the line of the Wall itself there are a number of coastal forts both in the East (e.g. [[Inveresk]]) and West (Outerwards and Lurg Moor), which should be considered as outposts and/or supply bases to the Wall itself. In addition a number of forts farther north were brought back into service in the [[Gask Ridge]] area, including [[Ardoch fort|Ardoch]], [[Strageath]], [[Bertha (Perth)]]<ref name="L.Keppie, Scotland's Roman Remains 1986"/> and probably Dalginross and Cargill.<ref>D.J.Woolliscroft & B.Hoffmann, Romes First Frontier. The Flavian occupation of Northern Scotland (Stroud: Tempus 2006)</ref> [[File:Romanwallinscotl00macduoft raw 0387.png|thumb|right|upright=1.8| RIB 2193. Distance Slab of the [[Legio II Augusta|Second Legion]]<ref>{{cite web|title= RIB 2193. Distance Slab of the Second Legion |url=https://romaninscriptionsofbritain.org/inscriptions/2193|website=Roman Inscriptions of Britain|accessdate=18 November 2017}}</ref> George MacDonald calls in no. 6 in the 2nd edition of his book ''The Roman Wall in Scotland''.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Macdonald|first1=Sir George|title=The Roman wall in Scotland, by Sir George Macdonald|date=1934|publisher=The Clarendon press|location=Oxford|page=373–376|edition=2d ed., rev., enl., and in great part rewritten|url=https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=uc1.b3760345;view=2up;seq=526;size=200|accessdate=11 October 2017}}</ref> [[George Macdonald (archaeologist)|He]] says it was found near the farm at [[Summerston]] on the banks of the [[River Kelvin|Kelvin]]. It has been scanned and a video produced.<ref>{{cite web|title=Distance Slab of the Second Legion , Balmuildy|url=https://vimeo.com/129136081|accessdate=25 November 2017|date=2015-05-28}}</ref>]] Recent research by Glasgow University has shown that the distance stones, stone sculptures unique to the Antonine Wall which were embedded in the wall to mark the lengths built by each legion, were brightly painted unlike their present bare appearance.<ref>University News: https://www.gla.ac.uk/news/headline_579010_en.html</ref> These stones are preserved in the University's [[Hunterian Collection|museum]] and are said to be the best-preserved examples of statuary from any Roman frontier.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Brock |first1=John F. |title=THE DISTANCE SLABS OF THE ANTONINE WALL : The Surveyors' Record Carved in Stone! |url=https://www.fig.net/resources/proceedings/fig_proceedings/fig2018/papers/fig09a/FIG09A_brock_9217.pdf#page=17 |website=International Federation of Surveyors |accessdate=5 June 2018}}</ref> Several of the slabs have been analysed by various techniques including portable [[X-ray fluorescence]] (pXRF). Tiny remnants of paint have been detected by [[surface-enhanced Raman spectroscopy]] (SERS). Several of the distance slabs have been scanned and 3-D videos produced. There are plans to reproduce the slabs, both digitally and in real physical copies, with their authentic colours.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Krakowka |first1=Kathryn |title=Reading the painting on the wall |url=https://www.archaeology.co.uk/articles/reading-the-painting-on-the-wall.htm |accessdate=30 May 2018 |agency=Current Archaeology |issue=CA 340 |date=30 May 2018}}</ref> A copy of [[The Bridgeness Slab|the Bridgeness Slab]] has already been made and can be found in [[Bo'ness]]. It is also expected that lottery funding will allow replicas of distance markers to be placed along the length of the wall.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Paterson |first1=Kirsteen |title=Scotland's Roman heritage to be remembered with Antonine Wall installations |url=http://www.thenational.scot/news/16956037.scotlands-roman-heritage-to-be-remembered-with-antonine-wall-installations/ |accessdate=6 October 2018 |agency=The National |date=3 October 2018}}</ref>
[[File:Antonine wall.JPG|thumb|alt=swale with wall foundation|The Antonine Wall, looking east, from [[Bar Hill Fort|Bar Hill]] between [[Twechar]] and [[Croy, North Lanarkshire|Croy]]]]
==Abandonment== The wall was abandoned only eight years after completion{{citation needed|reason=Some materials claims either abandoned Antonine Wall was after Antonines' death in 161 (https://www.encyclopedia.com/history/modern-europe/british-and-irish-history/wall-antoninus) and others says that was in 162 (http://www.castlesfortsbattles.co.uk/central_west_scotland/bearsden_roman_fort.html) or even 163 (http://roman-britain.co.uk/frontier/antonine_wall.htm)|date=November 2018}}, when the [[Roman legion]]s withdrew to [[Hadrian's Wall]] in 162, and over time may have reached an accommodation with the [[Brythonic languages|Brythonic]] tribes of the area, whom they may have fostered as possible [[buffer state]]s which would later become [[Hen Ogledd|"The Old North"]]. After a series of attacks in 197, the emperor [[Septimius Severus]] arrived in Scotland in 208 to secure the frontier, and repaired parts of the wall. Although this re-occupation only lasted a few years, the wall is sometimes referred to by later Roman historians as the '''[[Wall of Severus|Severan Wall]]'''. This led to later scholars like [[Bede]] mistaking references to the Antonine Wall for ones to [[Hadrian's Wall#After Hadrian|Hadrian's Wall]].
==Post-Roman history== In the centuries since the Antonine Wall lay abandoned it had an influence over culture between the Forth and the Clyde.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Maldonado |first1=Adrián |title=The Early Medieval Antonine Wall |journal=Britannia |date=November 2015 |volume=46 |pages=225 – 245 |doi=10.1017/S0068113X15000124 |url=https://s3.amazonaws.com/academia.edu.documents/39051785/Maldonado_2015_-_Early_Medieval_Antonine_Wall.pdf?AWSAccessKeyId=AKIAIWOWYYGZ2Y53UL3A&Expires=1531157578&Signature=3Ld1chp3LO7qu327sHMhDEP0sjE%3D&response-content-disposition=inline%3B%20filename%3DThe_Early_Medieval_Antonine_Wall.pdf |accessdate=9 July 2018|dead-url=yes}}</ref>
===Gildas and Bede===
Writing in AD 730, [[Bede]] following Gildas mistakenly ascribes the construction of the Antonine Wall to the Britons in [[s:Ecclesiastical History of the English People/Book 1#5|''Historia Ecclesiastica'' 1.12]]:
{{quote|text=The islanders built the wall which they had been told to raise, not of stone, since they had no workmen capable of such a work, but of sods, made it of no use. Nevertheless, they carried it for many miles between the two bays or inlets of the sea of which we have spoken; to the end that where the protection of the water was wanting, they might use the rampart to defend their borders from the irruptions of the enemies. Of the work there erected, that is, of a rampart of great breadth and height, there are evident remains to be seen at this day [AD 730]. It begins at about two miles distance from the monastery of Aebbercurnig [Abercorn], west of it, at a place called in the Pictish language Peanfahel, but in the English tongue, Penneltun [Kinneil], and running westward, ends near the city of Aicluith [Dumbarton].<ref name="ReferenceA">Bede ''Historia Ecclesiastica'' Book I Chapter 12</ref>}}
Bede associated Gildas' turf wall with the Antonine Wall. As for Hadrian's Wall, Bede again follows Gildas: {{quote|text= [the departing Romans] thinking that it might be some help to the allies [Britons], whom they were forced to abandon, constructed a strong stone wall from sea to sea, in a straight line between the towns that had been there built for fear of the enemy, where Severus also had formerly built a rampart.<ref name="ReferenceA">Bede ''Historia Ecclesiastica'' Book I Chapter 12</ref>}}
Bede obviously identified Gildas' stone wall as Hadrian's Wall, but he sets its construction in the 5th century rather than the 120s, and does not mention Hadrian. And he would appear to have deduced that the ditch-and-mound barrier known as the Vallum (just to the south of, and contemporary with, Hadrian's Wall) was the rampart constructed by Severus. Many centuries would pass before just who built what became apparent.<ref>[http://www.dot-domesday.me.uk/s_wall.htm], From Dot to Domesday website</ref>
===Grim's Dyke=== In [[medieval]] histories, such as the chronicles of [[John of Fordun]], the wall is called ''Gryme's dyke''. Fordun says that the name came from the grandfather of the imaginary king Eugenius son of Farquahar. This evolved over time into Graham's dyke<ref>{{cite web|title=An Additional DESCRIPTION OF THE ROMAN WALL, IN SCOTLAND|url=https://ebooks.adelaide.edu.au/c/camden/william/britannia-gibson-1722/part159.html|accessdate=15 October 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Camden|first1=William|title=Britannia, or, A chorographical description of Great Britain and Ireland, together with the adjacent islands|date=1722|publisher=Printed by Mary Matthews, for Awnsham Churchill, and sold by William Taylor ...|location=London|pages=1283–1292|edition=vol 2|url=https://archive.org/stream/gri_britanniaora02camd#page/n375/mode/2up|accessdate=9 October 2017}}</ref> – a name still found in [[Bo'ness]] at the wall's eastern end – and then linked with [[Clan Graham]]. Of note is that Graeme in some parts of Scotland is a nickname for the devil, and Gryme's Dyke would thus be the Devil's Dyke, mirroring the name of the Roman [[Limes]] in Southern Germany often called 'Teufelsmauer'. Grímr and Grim are bynames for [[Odin]] or [[Wodan]], who might be credited with the wish to build earthworks in unreasonably short periods of time. This name is the same one found as ''Grim's Ditch'' several times in England in connection with early ramparts: for example, near [[Wallingford, Oxfordshire|Wallingford]], Oxfordshire or between [[Berkhamsted]] (Herts) and [[Bradenham, Buckinghamshire|Bradenham]] (Bucks). Other names used by antiquarians include the Wall of Pius and the Antonine Vallum, after Antoninus Pius.<ref>Earthwork of England: prehistoric, Roman, Saxon, Danish, Norman and mediæval - Page 496, by Arthur Hadrian Allcroft</ref><ref>'Transactions of the Woolhope Naturalists' Field Club - Page 255, by Woolhope Naturalists' Field Club, Hereford, England, G. H. Jack, 1905</ref> [[Hector Boece]] in his 1527 ''History of Scotland'' called it the "wall of [[Abercorn]]", repeating the story that it had been destroyed by Graham.<ref>Boece, Hector, ''Historia Gentis Scotorum'', (1527), book 7, chapter 16</ref>
===World Heritage status=== [[File:Near infra-red kite aerial photo of Kinneil Roman Fortlet.jpg|thumb|alt=near infrared photograph of Roman fort|A near infra-red kite aerial photograph of Kinneil Roman Fortlet, near [[Bo'ness]] at the eastern end of the Antonine Wall.]] The UK government's nomination of the Antonine Wall for [[World Heritage Site|World Heritage status]] to the international conservation body [[UNESCO]] was first officially announced in 2003.<ref>{{cite news | title = Roman wall builds heritage claim | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/scotland/2789239.stm | publisher = BBC News | date = 22 February 2003 | accessdate = 2007-05-24 }}</ref> It has been backed by the [[Scottish Government]] since 2005<ref>{{cite news | title = Roman wall heritage bid backing | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/scotland/4090692.stm | publisher = BBC News | date = 14 June 2005 | accessdate = 2007-05-24 }}</ref> and by Scotland's then Culture Minister [[Patricia Ferguson]] since 2006.<ref>{{cite news | title = World Heritage bid hope for wall | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/scotland/5100616.stm | publisher = BBC News | date = 20 June 2006 | accessdate = 2007-05-24 }}</ref> It became the UK's official nomination in late January 2007,<ref>{{cite news | title = World Heritage support for wall | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/scotland/tayside_and_central/6290053.stm | publisher = BBC News | date = 23 January 2007 | accessdate = 2007-05-24 }}</ref> and [[Member of the Scottish Parliament|MSPs]] were called to support the bid anew in May 2007.<ref>{{cite news | title = MSPs called to support Roman wall | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/scotland/tayside_and_central/6683339.stm | publisher = BBC News | date = 23 May 2007 | accessdate = 2007-05-24 }}</ref> The Antonine Wall was listed as an extension to the World Heritage Site "Frontiers of the Roman Empire" on 7 July 2008.<ref>[http://whc.unesco.org/en/newproperties/ UNESCO World Heritage Centre. New Inscribed Properties]</ref><ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/scotland/tayside_and_central/7494680.stm "Wall gains World Heritage status'"] BBC News. Retrieved 8 July 2008.</ref> Though the Antonine Wall is mentioned in the text, it does not appear on UNESCO's map of world heritage properties.<ref>[http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/430 Frontiers of the Roman Empire - UNESCO World Heritage Centre<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
===Historic Environment Scotland=== Several individual sites along the line of the wall are in the care of [[Historic Environment Scotland|Historic Scotland]]. These are at: {{div col|colwidth=22em}} * [[Bar Hill Fort]]<ref>{{cite web|title=BARHILL ROMAN FORT|url=http://www.castlesfortsbattles.co.uk/central_west_scotland/bar_hill_roman_fort.html|website=castles forts battles|accessdate=13 August 2016}}</ref> * [[Bearsden#Roman|Bearsden Bath House]] * [[Castlecary]]<ref>{{cite web|title=CASTLECARY ROMAN FORT and CASTLECARY TOWER|url=http://www.castlesfortsbattles.co.uk/central_west_scotland/castlecary.html|website=castles forts battles|accessdate=13 August 2016}}</ref> * [[Croy Hill]] * [[Dullatur]] * [[Rough Castle]]<ref>{{cite web|title=ROUGH CASTLE|url=http://www.castlesfortsbattles.co.uk/central_west_scotland/rough_castle.html|website=castles forts battles|accessdate=13 August 2016}}</ref> * [[Seabegs Wood]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Rough Castle to Castlecary|url=http://www.antoninewall.co.uk/rough_castle_castlecary.html|website=Antonine Wall|accessdate=3 July 2017}}</ref> * [[Watling Lodge]] * [[Westerwood]], [[Cumbernauld]] {{div col end}}
All sites are unmanned and open at all reasonable times.<ref>[http://www.historic-scotland.gov.uk/index/places/propertyresults/propertydetail.htm?PropID=PL_305&PropName=Antonine%20Wall:%20Overview Historic Scotland - Antonine Wall: Overview Property Detail<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
==Mapping the wall== The first capable effort to systematically map<ref>{{cite web|title=OS Six Inch 1st edition, 1843-1882|url=http://maps.nls.uk/geo/explore/#zoom=16&lat=55.9669&lon=-4.0400&layers=5&b=1|website=National Library of Scotland|publisher=Ordnance Survey|accessdate=3 July 2017}}</ref> the Antonine Wall was undertaken in 1764 by [[William Roy]],<ref>{{Cite book |last=Hübner |first=Emil |year=1886 |editor-last=Hodgkin |editor-first=Thomas |contribution=The Roman Annexation of Britain |title=Archaeologia Aeliana |volume=XI |series=New |publisher=[[Society of Antiquaries of Newcastle upon Tyne]] |publication-date= |location=Newcastle-Upon-Tyne |pages=82–116 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=4_4RAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA82 }}</ref> the forerunner of the [[Ordnance Survey]]. He provided accurate and detailed drawings of its remains, and where the wall has been destroyed by later development, his maps and drawings are now the only reliable record of it. Modern computer techniques like using [[GIS]] can now map the wall in 3-dimensions which makes it much easier to study for example how visible forts and fortlets were to their fellow soldiers along the wall.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Dyčka |first1=Michal |title=To See and to be Seen – the Antonine Wall in the Context of Spatial Analysis |journal=Studia Hercynia |date=2016 |volume=20 |issue=2 |pages=40–46 |url=https://dspace.cuni.cz/bitstream/handle/20.500.11956/97514/1484308_michal_dycka_40-66_pl.pdf?sequence=1 |accessdate=9 July 2018}}</ref>
== In fiction == The Antonine Wall is mentioned in [[Max Brooks]]' novel ''[[World War Z]]: An Oral History of the Zombie War'' (2006) as the last line of defense in Great Britain against the [[zombies]].
The Northern Wall is also depicted in some of [[Rosemary Sutcliff]]'s historical fiction novels: as a fully functioning outpost of Roman power in ''[[The Mark of the Horse Lord]]'' (1965) and as an abandoned ruin in ''Frontier Wolf'' (1980).<ref>{{cite book|date=1980|author=Sutcliff, Rosemary|title=Frontier Wolf|url=https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/1195090.Frontier_Wolf}} </ref>
[[File:The Antonine Wall, Rome's final frontier, the Hunterian Museum..JPG|thumb|upright=3|right|The Antonine Wall, Rome's final frontier, the [[Hunterian Museum and Art Gallery|Hunterian Museum]].]] [[File:Romans (Antonine Guard Living History Society) parade before the Roman vs Picts 5k race, Callendar House.jpg|thumb|upright=3|right|Romans (Antonine Guard Living History Society) parade before the Roman vs Picts 5k race, Callendar House<ref>{{cite web|title=Antonine Guard Living History Society|url=http://www.theantonineguard.org.uk/|website=THE ANTONINE GUARD|accessdate=26 May 2018}}</ref>]] {{clr}}

revision.comment: added the interesting fact that Mrs. Drew was Lionel, Ethel and John Barrymore's grandmother.
revision.text:
{{distinguish|Arch Street Opera House}} '''The Arch Street Theatre''' in [[Philadelphia]], [[Pennsylvania]] was during the 19th century one of the three main Philadelphia theaters for plays; the other two were the [[Walnut Street Theatre]] and the [[Chestnut Street Theatre]]. The Arch Street Theatre opened on 1 October 1828 under the management of [[William B. Wood (actor)|William B. Wood]]. The building's architect was [[John Haviland]].<ref name=FreeLibrary>[https://libwww.freelibrary.org/digital/item/39189 Arch Street Theatre, Free Library of Philadelphia]</ref>
==History== The building which housed the Arch Street Theatre was located between 6th and 7th Streets at 819 [[Arch Street (Philadelphia)|Arch Street]]. Famous performers, such as [[Fanny Davenport]], [[Joseph Jefferson]], and [[Charlotte Cushman]], played at what was popularly called "The Arch".<ref>{{cite journal|author=Pawlak, Debra Ann|title=The Lady in Charge|journal=Pennsylvania Heritage Magazine|volume=XL|number=3|date=Summer 2014|url=http://www.phmc.state.pa.us/portal/communities/pa-heritage/louisa-lane-drew-lady-in-charge.html}}</ref> [[John Wilkes Booth]] joined the theatre's stock company in 1857 and played for a full season. He appeared occasionally at the Arch during the 1850s and early 1860s.<ref>[http://digitallibrary.hsp.org/index.php/Detail/Object/Show/object_id/5117 Arch Street Theatre, Historical Society of Pennsylvania]</ref>
In the 1830s [[Edwin Forrest]] played many successful roles at the Arch, and several original plays written at his request debuted there.<ref>{{cite book|author=Hornblow, Arthur|title=A History of the Theatre in America|page=309|volume=vol. 2|year=1919|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=thA9AAAAYAAJ&pg=PA309}}</ref>
In 1832 the Arch Street Theatre had an entire company of American actors, which was a first for American theater companies.<ref name=MrsJohnDrewp40>{{cite book|url=https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=uc1.$b113925;view=1up;seq=60|title=Autobiographical sketch of Mrs. John Drew|page=40}}</ref> The managers were William Forrest, William Duffy, and William Jones.<ref>{{cite book|author=Ludlow, Noah Miller|title=Dramatic life as I found it|year=1880|pages=314–315|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=oYkVAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA314}}</ref> The company included [[James Edward Murdoch|James E. Murdoch]].<ref name=MrsJohnDrewp40/>
In 1860 the stockholders of the Arch suggested that [[Louisa Lane Drew]] should assume the management, and in 1861 the theatre was opened under the name "Mrs. John Drew's Arch Street Theatre". Louisa Lane Drew was the grandmother of Lionel, Ethel and John Barrymore.<ref>The House of Barrymores, Margot Peters</ref>
{{blockquote|For the next thirty-one years the theatre-going public was treated to one of the greatest of all American stock companies. After Drew's tenure ended in 1892 the theatre's stature went into a slow decline until the building itself was demolished in 1936.<ref name=FreeLibrary/>}}
During the third season under Louisa Lane Drew's management, [[Lester Wallack]], [[Edward Loomis Davenport|E. L. Davenport]], and [[Edwin Booth]] acted at the Arch.<ref name=MrsJohnDrewp110>{{cite book|url=https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=uc1.$b113925;view=1up;seq=128|title=Autobiographical sketch of Mrs. John Drew|page=110}}</ref>
In the summer of 1863 the theatre was pulled down and rebuilt (with red plush seats and crystal chandeliers) from the stage to the façade;<ref name=MrsJohnDrewp110/> the seating capacity was one thousand, nine-hundred eleven.<ref>[https://www.philadelphiabuildings.org/pab/app/pj_display.cfm/16554 Arch Street Theatre, philadelphiabuildings.org]</ref>
In 1898 [[Moishe Finkel|Morris Finkel]] rented the Arch Street Theatre and presented Yiddish theater for several months, including one week of performances by [[Keni Liptzin]]; however Finkel soon abandoned the project and the Arch returned to vaudeville. In 1909 Mike (Mordechai) Thomashefsky took over the Arch and presented both vaudeville and Yiddish theatre until his death in 1932.<ref>[http://www.museumoffamilyhistory.com/jqp-archstreet.htm The Arch Street Theatre, The Jewish Quarter of Philadelphia, The Museum of Family History]</ref><ref>[http://www.museumoffamilyhistory.com/yt/lex/T/thomashefsky-mike.htm Mike (Mordechai) Thomashefsky, LIves in the Yiddish Theatre, Museum of Family History]</ref>

The '''Architecture of Macau''' is the architecture that is found in [[Macau]]. Macau has diverse architecture from the casinos in its casino region to its tallest building, [[Grand Lisboa]] (which stands at 258 metres). Macau is influenced by both [[Cantonese]] and [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]] cultures.
== Background == [[Macau]] is a large city located off the south coast of [[Mainland China]], with a population of approximately 630,000 people.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://worldpopulationreview.com/countries/macau-population/|title=Macau Population 2018 (Demographics, Maps, Graphs)|website=worldpopulationreview.com|access-date=2018-11-06}}</ref> and the official native languages being [[Cantonese]] and [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]]. Macau is classified as a special administrative region (SAR), meaning it has separate executive, legislative and judicial systems to China. Macau was previously a Portuguese dependency, which ended in 1999 when it became autonomous<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.investopedia.com/terms/s/special-administrative-region.asp|title=Special Administrative Region - SAR|last=Staff|first=Investopedia|date=2013-01-06|work=Investopedia|access-date=2018-11-06|language=en-US}}</ref>. The [[architecture]] of Macau encompasses a mixture of [[World Heritage site|world heritage]] listed and modern buildings, as well as multiple [[Bridge|bridges]] and [[Tunnel|tunnels]].
== Casinos in Macau == [[File:Casinos, Macao, 2013-08-08, DD 01.jpg|thumb|Cluster of casinos in Macau.]] Within the region of Macau, there is a total of 50 [[Casino|Casinos]] spread across the cities of Macau, [[Cotai]] and [[Taipa]]. Being known as the ‘[[Las Vegas]] of China’, Macau has a substantial amount of casinos compared to other regions, with 30 in the city of Macau, 14 in Cotai and 6 in Taipa<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.worldcasinodirectory.com/macau/casino-list|title=Macau Casino List|website=www.worldcasinodirectory.com|access-date=2018-11-06}}</ref>. An example of a famous Casino in Macau is the ‘[[MGM Macau|MGM MACAU]]’, which stands at 154 metres tall<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.mgm.mo/en/macau/about-us/property-overview|title=Property Overview {{!}} MGM MACAU|website=www.mgm.mo|access-date=2018-11-06}}</ref> and is located near the southern coast of the northern region of Macau<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.google.com.au/maps/place/MGM+Macau/@22.1771959,113.5362327,12.75z/data=!4m7!3m6!1s0x0:0x7bb2ff131ed87a29!5m1!1s2018-10-28!8m2!3d22.1860312!4d113.5478016|title=MGM Macau|website=MGM Macau|language=en|access-date=2018-11-06}}</ref>. Other casinos in Macau include the [[Grand Lisboa]] Casino & Hotel, [[Wynn Macau|Wynn Casino Macau]] and [[Sands Macao|Sands Macao Hotel]], all of which are clustered around each other and near the MGM MACAU. This architectural cluster centralises the casinos near the southern coast of Macau, creating a ‘hub’ for [[gambling]] and accommodation.
== Tall buildings in Macau == Within the [[region]] of Macau, there are 20 completed buildings and 2 under construction that are above 150 metres tall, which ranks Macau as #48 in the world by number of buildings over 150 metres<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.skyscrapercenter.com/city/macau|title=Macau - The Skyscraper Center|website=www.skyscrapercenter.com|access-date=2018-11-06}}</ref>. Macau's first building over 150m was the [[Bank of China Building, Macau|Bank of China]], which is located in the City of Macau and currently stands at 163m (535 feet) tall<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.skyscrapercenter.com/building/bank-of-china/3179|title=Bank of China - The Skyscraper Center|website=www.skyscrapercenter.com|access-date=2018-11-06}}</ref>. [[File:Macau-Morpheus-01.jpg|thumb|188x188px|Morpheus Building, Macau.]] [[File:Grand Lisboa, Macau - panoramio.jpg|left|thumb|168x168px|[[Grand Lisboa|Grand Lisboa, Macau]].]] The tallest completed building in Macau is the Grand Lisboa Casino & Hotel, with an architectural height to the tip of 258m (846 feet) and a residential height of 197.7m (649 feet). These statistics rank the height of the building as #332 in the world. The building began construction in 2003 and was completed in 2008. Functioning as a hotel/casino and made from predominately [[steel]], [[concrete]] and [[glass]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.skyscrapercenter.com/building/grand-lisboa/789|title=Grand Lisboa - The Skyscraper Center|website=www.skyscrapercenter.com|access-date=2018-11-06}}</ref>, it was designed by architectural company “Dennis Lau & Ng Chun Man Architects & Engineers (HK) Ltd. (DLN)” as their 9th tallest building<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.skyscrapercenter.com/company/110|title=Dennis Lau & Ng Chun Man Architects & Engineers (HK) Ltd. (DLN) - The Skyscraper Center|website=www.skyscrapercenter.com|access-date=2018-11-06}}</ref>. The Grand Lisboa has 48 floors above ground and 4 below, with 433 [[hotel]] rooms and 338 parking spots.
Macau's most recently constructed tall building, finished in 2018, is the Morpheus building, which is a multi story building that stands at 155.2m (509 feet) tall with 40 floors above ground and 770 hotel rooms. Architecturally, the Morpheus is unconventionally constructed with an [[exoskeleton]] design and 3 separate openings that travel through the middle of the building<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.scmp.com/magazines/style/travel-food/article/2146778/morpheus-hotel-opens-june-city-dreams-macau|title=Morpheus hotel opens this June in City of Dreams, Macau|work=South China Morning Post|access-date=2018-11-06}}</ref>. The building was designed by the late [[architect]] Dame Zaha Hadid<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cityofdreamsmacau.com/en/stay/morpheus/index.html#architect|title=Morpheus Luxury {{!}} City of Dreams Macau|website=www.cityofdreamsmacau.com|language=en|access-date=2018-11-06}}</ref> and was developed by Melco Crown Entertainment Limited<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.emporis.com/statistics/tallest-buildings/city/102758/macau-china|title=Macau {{!}} Statistics {{!}} EMPORIS|last=GmbH|first=Emporis|website=www.emporis.com|access-date=2018-11-06}}</ref>.
Within the table below, is a list of the top 20 tallest completed buildings in Macau ranked upon structural height<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.emporis.com/statistics/tallest-buildings/city/102758/macau-china|title=Macau {{!}} Statistics {{!}} EMPORIS|last=GmbH|first=Emporis|website=www.emporis.com|access-date=2018-11-06}}</ref>. The amount of floors only includes above ground floors. {| class="wikitable" |+Top 20 Tallest Buildings in Macau !Rank !Building Name !Floors !Height (m) !Year |- |1 |[[Grand Lisboa]] |48 |258 |2008 |- |2 |[[L'Arc Macau]] |53 |217 |2009 |- |3 |[[Wynn Macau|Encore at Wynn Macau]] |40 |206 |2010 |- |4 |[[The Praia Block 1]] |56 |185 |2009 |- |5 |[[The Praia Block 2]] |56 |185 |2008 |- |6 |[[The Praia Block 3]] |56 |185 |2008 |- |7 |[[The Praia Block 4]] |56 |185 |2008 |- |8 |[[Mandarin Oriental Macau]] |42 |165 |2010 |- |9 |[[Bank of China Building, Macau|Bank of China Building]] |38 |163 |1991 |- |10 |[[The Buckingham Macau|The Buckingham]] |50 |160 |2009 |- |11 |[[Galaxy Macau Phase II]] |36 |160 |2015 |- |12 |[[Altira Macau]] |32 |160 |2007 |- |13 |[[Lai San Kok Macau|Lai San Kok]] |52 |156 |2008 |- |14 |[https://www.cityofdreamsmacau.com/en/stay/morpheus/index.html Morpheus] |40 |155 |2018 |- |15 |[[MGM Macau|MGM Grand Macau]] |35 |154 |2007 |- |16 |[[Studio City (Macau)|Studio City]] |32 |152 |2015 |- |17 |[[The Venetian Macao|The Venetian Macau]] |39 |151 |2007 |- |18 |[[MGM Grand Paradise]] |36 |151 |2018 |- |19 |[[Crown Towers Macau|Crown Towers]] |36 |151 |2009 |- |20 |[[Galaxy StarWorld Hotel]] |33 |148 |2006 |} [[File:Macau tower by night.jpg|thumb|[[Macau Tower]] at night.|alt=]] Technically the tallest structure in Macau, however not classified under the same category as the tallest buildings in Macau, the [[Macau Tower]] (pictured below) is 338m (1102.9 feet) tall to the tip. The tower began construction in 1998 and was opened on the 19th December, 2001. It was designed by architect, Gordon Moller and was inspired by the [[Sky Tower (Auckland)|Sky Tower in Auckland, New Zealand]]<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.macautower.com.mo/tower-overview/|title=Tower Overview - Macau Tower|work=Macau Tower|access-date=2018-11-06|language=en-US}}</ref>. It currently holds the [[Guinness World Records|Guinness World Record]] for the highest commercial [[Bungee jumping|bungy jump]] point at 233m (764 feet) and the first person to jump was film star [[Edison Chen]] (China) in 2006<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.guinnessworldrecords.com/world-records/highest-commercial-bungee-jump-facility|title=Highest commercial bungee jump facility|work=Guinness World Records|access-date=2018-11-06|language=en-GB}}</ref>. [[File:West section of Hong Kong-Zhuhai-Macau Bridge (20180902174105).jpg|thumb|West section of the [[Hong Kong–Zhuhai–Macau Bridge|Zhuhai Bridge]].]]
== Bridges and tunnels == The [[Hong Kong–Zhuhai–Macau Bridge|Zhuhai Bridge]], opened in October 2018, is the world's longest sea bridge, spanning 55 kilometres (34 miles) from [[Hong Kong]] to Macau and Mainland Chinese city; Zuhai<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-china-45937924|title=China opens longest sea-crossing bridge|date=2018-10-23|work=BBC News|access-date=2018-11-06|language=en-GB}}</ref>. The bridge cost approximately $20 Billion US Dollars to complete and was under construction from December 2009<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-china-45961705|title=Quiet start for world's longest sea crossing|date=2018-10-24|work=BBC News|access-date=2018-11-06|language=en-GB}}</ref>. The bridge is designed to last over 120 years, withstanding pressures from [[Earthquake|earthquakes]] and [[Typhoon|typhoons]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cnbc.com/hong-kong-macau-and-zhuhai-bridge-shapes-chinas-own-silicon-valley|title=A massive bridge is set to transform southern China|website=CNBC|access-date=2018-11-06}}</ref>. Through employing 400,000 tonnes of steel in its construction, with 30km worth of bridge above the [[Pearl River Delta]] and 7km worth of tunnel running between two [[Artificial island|artificial islands]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.hzmb.hk/eng/about_overview_01.html|title=HongKong-Zhuhai-Macao Bridge (HZMB) : HZMB Main Bridge|website=www.hzmb.hk|language=en|access-date=2018-11-06}}</ref>. The bridge is 3 lanes wide on each side and incorporates merging channels to transfer the traffic from the left to the right as it is technically in Chinese territory<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://abcnews.go.com/International/worlds-longest-sea-bridge-opens-macau-hong-kong/story?id=58662116|title=World's longest sea bridge to open after 9 years of construction|last=News|first=A. B. C.|date=2018-10-23|website=ABC News|language=en|access-date=2018-11-06}}</ref>. To use the bridge, drivers from Hong Kong will need to attain special permits, of which there are only 300<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.vox.com/world/2018/10/22/18010254/chain-bridge-hong-kong-macau-zhuhai|title=China’s new bridge will connect 70 million people — and give Beijing more power|work=Vox|access-date=2018-11-06}}</ref>.
[[File:Macao Friendship Bridge.jpg|left|thumb|212x212px|[[Amizade Bridge (Macau)|Point da Amizade]].]] [[File:Ponte de Sai Van.jpg|thumb|[[Sai Van Bridge|Sai Van Bridge.]]]] [[Amizade Bridge (Macau)|Point da Amizade]], which is Portuguese for the ‘friendship bridge’, connects the [[Macau Peninsula]] to Taipa Island and Pac On. With its construction beginning in June 1990, the bridge took almost 4 years to complete and was officially opened to [[Motor vehicle|motor vehicles]] in March 1994<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://macauantigo.blogspot.com/2010/05/ponte-da-amizade-desde-1994.html|title=Macau Antigo: Ponte da Amizade: desde 1994|last=Botas|first=João|date=30 May 2010|website=Macau Antigo|access-date=2018-11-06}}</ref>. The bridge spans over 4.7 kilometres (2.9 miles), with a maximum height of 30 metres above the sea and is 18 metres wide at its widest point, accommodating four lanes of traffic. The bridge has two crests at different points to allow for sea traffic to travel beneath<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://en.jmgrating.com/index.php?m=content&c=index&a=show&catid=10&id=17|title=Ponte de Amizade Macau-Nanhai Jimu Grating|website=en.jmgrating.com|language=en|access-date=2018-11-06}}</ref>. The [[Sai Van Bridge]], completed in December 2004, is also a sea bridge used to connect the Macau Peninsula and Taipa Island. The full length of the bridge is 2.2km (1.37 miles) long, with its [[Tower#Transportation support|pylon]] heights standing 85 metres above ground level<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://structurae.net/structures/sai-van-bridge|title=Sai Van Bridge (Macau, 2004) {{!}} Structurae|website=Structurae|language=en|access-date=2018-11-06}}</ref>. The bridge was designed by Pengest Planeamento to accommodate both road traffic and railway carriages and is built primarily from steel, steel cables and prestressed concrete<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://structurae.net/companies/pengest-planeamento-engenharia-e-gestao-lda|title=Pengest Planeamento, Engenharia e Gestão, Lda {{!}} Structurae|website=Structurae|language=en|access-date=2018-11-06}}</ref>. The total cost of the bridge was US$70 million<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bridgeweb.com/Macaus-Sai-Van-Bridge-completed/427|title=Macau's Sai Van Bridge completed - Bridge Design & Engineering (Bd & e)|date=2004-12-21|access-date=2018-11-06|language=en-GB}}</ref>.
[[File:Lotus-bridge-macau.jpg|thumb|256x256px|[[Lótus Bridge|Lotus Bridge]].]]
The smallest bridge in Macau, linking it across the border to [[Hengqin|Hengquin Island]] in Zhuhai, is the [[Lótus Bridge|Lotus Bridge]]. The bridge is approximately 900m long and its construction was completed in 1999<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://info.hktdc.com/shippers/vol23_3/vol23_3_fre03.html|title=New infrastructure enhances Macau, Zhuhai access (hktdc.com)|website=info.hktdc.com|access-date=2018-11-06}}</ref>. It specifically links the Cotai reclamation area of Macau to Hengquin Island with 3 lanes either side of the bridge. The bridge cost US$25 million to construct, which was shared between the Macau and Chinese governments<ref name=":0" />. The Lotus Bridge uses an ‘asymmetric partial cloverleaf’ design<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cntraveler.com/stories/2013-04-15/lotus-bridge-macau-maphead-ken-jennings|title=What Happens When Left-Hand Roads Meet Right-Hand Roads|last=Jennings|first=Ken|work=Condé Nast Traveler|access-date=2018-11-06|language=en}}</ref>, which is designed to re-direct traffic onto the correct side of the road when entering their respective countries, with China being the right and Macau being the left<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.quora.com/What-would-happen-on-the-border-of-a-country-that-drove-on-the-right-and-a-country-that-drove-on-the-left-How-would-you-be-able-to-drive-over-that-border|title=What would happen on the border of a country that drove on the right and a country that drove on the left? How would you be able to drive over that border? - Quora|website=www.quora.com|language=en|access-date=2018-11-06}}</ref>.
== Historic architecture == Most of the historic architecture and [[Landmark|landmarks]] within Macau are situated in the [[Historic Centre of Macau]], which is listed as a [[World Heritage site|UNESCO World Heritage Site]]<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=http://www.china-macau.com/attractions/macau-historic-center.htm|title=Macau Historic Centre - UNESCO World Heritage Sites in Macau|work=china-macau.com|access-date=2018-11-06|language=en-US}}</ref>. As seen within the table below, there are over 20 buildings and landmarks within the Historic Centre, however in terms of historic architecture, there are a bit less than 20. Some of the architecture within the Historic Centre includes the [[Holy House of Mercy]], [[Mandarin's House|Mandarin's House]] and the [[A-Ma Temple]]. As the Historic Centre of Macau is host to both buildings and landmarks, below is a list of the historic architecture, in no particular order, with the name and year constructed included<ref name=":1" />. {| class="wikitable" |+Historic Architecture in Macau !Name !Year |- |[[Ruins of St. Paul's|The Ruins of St. Paul's Cathedral]] |1640 |- |[[Na Tcha Temple]] |1888 |- |[[Walls of Macau|Section of the Old City Walls]] |1569 |- |[[A-Ma Temple]] |1488 |- |[[Mandarin's House|Mandarin's House Macau]] |1869 |- |[[St. Lawrence's Church macau|St. Lawrence's Church]] |1560 |- |[[Fortaleza do Monte|Fortaleza do Monte (Mount Fortress)]] |1617 |- |[[Holy House of Mercy]] |1569 |- |[[St. Joseph's Seminary and Church]] |1758 |- |[[St. Augustine's Church macau|St. Augustine's Church]] |1587 |- |[[Sir Robert Ho Tung Library|Sir Robert Ho-Tung Library]] |1894 |- |[[Dom Pedro V Theatre]] |1860 |- |[[Moorish Barracks]] |1874 |- |[[Lou Kau Mansion]] |1889 |- |[[Leal Senado Building]] |1784 |- |[[Guia Fortress]] |1638 |} The Holy House of Mercy is a [[UNESCO]] World Heritage site, constructed in 1569 and situated within the Historic Centre of Macau, in the [[Senado Square]]<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.secretmacau.com/holy-house-of-mercy/|title=Holy House of Mercy - Secret Macau|date=2016-12-01|work=Secret Macau|access-date=2018-11-06|language=en-US}}</ref>. The building was designed and constructed by D. Belchior Carneiro, following a [[Neoclassical architecture|neo-classical]] architectural trend<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://macaulifestyle.com/culture/architecture/the-holy-house-of-mercy-in-senado-square/|title=The Holy House of Mercy on Senado Square|last=Barbosa|first=Rui|date=2018-02-07|work=Macau Lifestyle|access-date=2018-11-06|language=en-US}}</ref> through incorporating 14 [[Arch|arches]] on the face and stands 2 stories high. It served as a [[Clinic|medical clinic]] for some time, later becoming an [[orphanage]]<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=http://www.scmm.mo/frontend/content/index.php?id=7&hl=en|title=澳門仁慈堂 - Macao Holy House of Mercy - Santa Casa da Misericórdia de Macau - History|website=www.scmm.mo|access-date=2018-11-06}}</ref>. It is the oldest social solidarity institution in the Macau [[Special administrative regions of China|Special Administrative Region]] and has undergone multiple [[Renovation|renovations]], with the most recent in 2003 on the building's Rehabilitation Centre for the Blind<ref name=":2" />.
One of the oldest structures in and officially the oldest [[temple]] in Macau, the A-Ma Temple was built in 1488 on the southwest Macau Peninsula<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.china-macau.com/outer-harbour/a-ma-temple.htm|title=A-Ma Temple - Macau Outer Harbour Attractions|work=china-macau.com|access-date=2018-11-06|language=en-US}}</ref>. It is made up of six separate architectural components within the entire vicinity, primarily using [[Rock (geology)|stone]], [[Brick|bricks]] and [[granite]] to build the temple. Pictured below, a notable aspect of the temple is the Gate Pavilion, which measures to be 4.5 metres wide and is made entirely from granite<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.wh.mo/en/site/detail/1|title=A-Ma Temple - MACAO WORLD HERITAGE|website=www.wh.mo|language=zh-cn|access-date=2018-11-06}}</ref>.
The Mandarin's House, built in 1869 and located at No. 10 Travessa de António da Silva<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.wh.mo/mandarinhouse/en/location/|title=Mandarin's House {{!}} Location|website=www.wh.mo|access-date=2018-11-06}}</ref>, is a traditional Chinese styled compound that once housed [[Chinese literature|Chinese Literary]] personality [[Zheng Guanying|Zhen g Guanying]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.wh.mo/en/site/detail/4|title=Mandarin's House - MACAO WORLD HERITAGE|website=www.wh.mo|language=zh-cn|access-date=2018-11-06}}</ref>. The compound covers approximately 4,000 square metres of land and it encompasses architectural elements of [[Art Deco]] as well as traditional Chinese styling with [[Western world|Western influence]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.wh.mo/mandarinhouse/en/introduction/|title=Mandarin's House {{!}} Introduction|website=www.wh.mo|access-date=2018-11-06}}</ref>. In 2001 the Government took over the complex from its private owners and in 2005 it became a UNESCO World Heritage Site<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.secretmacau.com/mandarins-house/|title=Mandarin's House - Secret Macau|date=2016-12-17|work=Secret Macau|access-date=2018-11-06|language=en-US}}</ref>

{{about|the profession|the New York recording studio|A & R Recording|the Australian bookseller|Angus & Robertson}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2012}} '''Artists and repertoire''' ('''A&R''') is the division of a [[record label]] or music publishing company that is responsible for talent scouting and overseeing the artistic development of [[recording artist]]s and songwriters.{{Cite book | last = Cook | first = Richard | author-link = | year = 2005 | title = Richard Cook's Jazz Encyclopedia | publisher = Penguin Books | location = London | isbn = 0-141-00646-3 | pages = 16 }} It also acts as a liaison between artists and the record label or publishing company; every activity involving artists to the point of album release is generally considered under the purview, and responsibility, of A&R. ==Responsibilities== ===Finding talent=== The A&R division of a record label is responsible for finding new [[recording artist]]s and bringing those artists to the record company. Personnel in the A&R division are expected to understand the current tastes of the market and to be able to find artists that will be commercially successful. For this reason, A&R people are often young and many are musicians, [[music journalists]] or [[record producers]].{{sfn|Albini|1993}} An A&R executive is authorized to offer a [[record contract]], often in the form of a "deal memo": a short informal document that establishes a business relationship between the recording artist and the record company.{{sfn|Albini|1993}} The actual contract negotiations will typically be carried out by rival [[entertainment lawyer]]s hired by the musician's [[artist manager|manager]] and the record company.{{sfn|Krasilovsky|Shemel|Gross|Feinstein|2007}} A&R executives rely mostly on the [[word of mouth]] of trusted associates, critics and business contacts, rather than on unsolicited demo tapes.{{sfn|Weissman|2003|p=25}} They also tend to favor the bands that play in the same city as the record label's offices.{{sfn|Weissman|2003|p=25}} ===Overseeing the recording process=== The A&R division of a record label oversees the [[sound recording|recording]] and format process. This includes helping the artist to find the right record producer, scheduling time in a recording studio and advising the artist on all aspects of making a high-quality recording. They work with the artist to choose the best songs (i.e.[[Wiktionary:repertoire|repertoire]]) to record. For artists who do not write their own music, the A&R person will assist in finding songs and songwriters. A&R executives maintain contact with their counterparts at [[Music publisher (popular music)|music publishing companies]] to get new songs and material from songwriters and producers. As the record nears completion, the A&R department works closely with the artist to determine whether the record is acceptable to the record company. This process may include suggesting that new songs need to be written or that some album tracks need to be re-recorded. A key issue is whether the album has a single: a particular track which can be used to [[marketing|market]] the record on radio. ===Assisting with marketing and promotion=== Once the record is completed, the A&R department consults with marketing, [[radio promotion|promotion]], the [[recording artist|artist]] and their management to choose one or more singles to help promote the record. ==History and influence== The tastes of particular A&R executives have influenced the course of music history. A&R man [[John H. Hammond]] discovered [[Billie Holiday]], [[Bob Dylan]], [[Aretha Franklin]] and [[Bruce Springsteen]]. Hammond's colleagues were initially skeptical of these artists because none of them appeared to be creating "commercial" music. Hammond's instincts proved to be correct, and these artists went on to sell hundreds of millions of records.{{sfn|Prial|2006}} [[George Daly (music executive)|George Daly]], Hammond's colleague at Columbia Records, proved the same instinct with bands as varied as outliers as [[The Tubes]] and [[Tool (band)|Tool]] during his career. [[David Geffen Company|Geffen Records]]' Gary Gersh signed the band [[Nirvana (band)|Nirvana]] at a time when [[alternative rock]] music was not considered commercial.{{sfn|Shoemer|1992}} Gersh was able to convince his co-workers to push the record in spite of their misgivings.{{sfn|Goldberg|2009|p=179-180}} In cases like these, A&R people have radically changed the direction of popular musical tastes and introduced large numbers of people to new sounds. This kind of prescience is, however, the exception rather than the rule. Historically, A&R executives have tended to sign new artists that fit into recent trends and who resemble acts that are currently successful. For example, [[Columbia Records]]' A&R man in the 1950s, [[Mitch Miller]], favored traditional pop singers like [[Guy Mitchell]] and [[Patti Page]], and rejected early rock-'n'-rollers [[Elvis Presley]] and [[Buddy Holly]]. This "trend following" mindset has generated several waves of narrowly defined genres, leading to a perception of triteness, including [[teen pop]] (1998–2001), [[alternative rock]] (1993–1996), [[glam metal]] (1986–1991) and [[disco]] (1976–1978). Trend following can be counter-productive, since it has often led to a [[Backlash (sociology)|backlash]]. Towards the end of the life of each wave, record companies have found themselves faced with enormous losses, as consumers' tastes changed. For example, at the end of the disco boom in 1978, millions of records were returned by record retailers, causing a deep recession in the music business that lasted until 1982, when [[Michael Jackson]]'s ''[[Thriller (Michael Jackson album)|Thriller]]'' finally brought the public back into record stores in large numbers.Disco boom: {{Harvtxt|Knopper|2009|pp=15–35}}. Teen pop boom: {{Harvtxt|Knopper|2009|pp=}}. Knopper discusses the way the industry has overreacted to these waves throughout his book. The general move towards more conservative and business-minded signings from the 1980s onwards is seen to be symptomatic of an industry where the most powerful figures are no longer music fans or people with musical backgrounds, but business people. Traditionally A&R executives were composers, arrangers and producers – [[Atlantic Records]]'s heads [[Jerry Wexler]] and [[Ahmet Ertegun]] were producers and composers respectively – but an A&R with musical ability and knowledge has become a rarity, with [[Ron Fair]] and [[Martin Kierszenbaum]] being notable recent exceptions.{{cite web |url=http://www.hitquarters.com/index.php3?page=intrview/opar/intrview_Richard_Niles_Interview.html |title=Interview with Richard Niles |publisher=[[HitQuarters]]|date=23 Apr 2007 |accessdate=17 Nov 2010}} The composer and arranger [[Richard Niles]] has said,
What you've got now is huge multinational companies where most of their A&R staff are businessmen. They’re people who look at music from the standpoint of marketing, not from the standpoint of music and talent. They will say, "Go out and get me anything that's popular now."
Hip hop group [[Wu-Tang Clan]] referenced this stereotype of the business-minded A&R executive in their single "[[Protect Ya Neck]]", metaphorically likening them to "mountain climbers".{{citenews|title=Wu-Tang Clan: 10 of the best|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/musicblog/2014/nov/26/wu-tang-clan-10-of-the-best|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=26 November 2014}}{{citenews|title=Wu-Tang Clan Still Sting|url=https://www.laweekly.com/music/wu-tang-clan-still-sting-2151230|work=[[LA Weekly]]|date=19 December 2007}} ==Regional variations== According to [[Rhythm King Records]] and [[Lizard King Records]] founder Martin Heath, the A&R community in the UK is more integrated than it is in the US, being very London-centric and encompassing a relatively small number of people.{{Cite web|url=http://www.hitquarters.com/index.php3?page=intrview/opar/intrview_MartinHeath.html |title=Interview With Martin Heath |publisher=[[HitQuarters]]|date=12 December 2005 |accessdate=20 Jun 2010}} "If scouts are chasing a band, you’ll see the same thirty people in one room. You get a herd mentality in the UK, but also some very diverse signings as well," he said in an interview with [[HitQuarters]]. Heath believes that in the USA it is more typical for A&R to wait until a band is established – having attracted other offers or achieved a level of sales – before taking action, a technique which often works out as being more expensive. ==Recent changes== {{See also|2000s in the music industry}} New forms of digital distribution have changed the relationship between consumers and the music they choose. Gerd Leonhard and others argue that the wide selection of music on digital services has allowed music consumers to bypass the traditional role of A&R.{{sfn|Kusek|Leonhard|2005}} In the wake of [[Music industry in the 21st century|declining record sales]], a large number of A&R staffers have been terminated.{{sfn|Knopper|2009|pp=220–221}} It is unclear whether A&R executives will shape the future of musical tastes as they have in the past. ==See also== *[[Chas Chandler]] *[[Clive Davis]] *[[Kara DioGuardi]] *[[David Geffen]] *[[Loren Israel]] *[[John Kalodner]] *[[Clyde Otis]] == Citations == {{Reflist}} == References == * {{Citation |last=Albini |first= Steve |author-link= Steve Albini |year=1993 |title= The Problem with Music |periodical= [[The Baffler]] |publication-place= Chicago |publisher= [[Thomas Frank]] |issue= 5 |url= http://www.negativland.com/albini.html}} (Reprinted in ''[[Maximum RocknRoll]]'' No. 133 (June 1994) and later various websites.) * {{Citation | last=Goldberg | first=Danny | title=Bumping into Geniuses | year=2009 | isbn=1-59240-483-9 }} * {{Citation | last = Knopper | first = Steve | year = 2009 | title = Appetite for self-destruction : the spectacular crash of the record industry in the digital age | isbn = 1-4165-5215-4 | publisher = Free Press | location = New York }} * {{Krasilovsky et al. 2007}} * {{Citation | last1 = Kusek | first1 = David | last2 = Leonhard | first2 = Gerd | year = 2005 | title = The future of music : manifesto for the digital music revolution | isbn = 0-87639-059-9 | publisher = Berklee Press | location = Boston }} * {{Citation | last = Prial | first = Dunstan | year = 2006 | title = The producer : John Hammond and the soul of American music | isbn = 0-374-11304-1 | publisher = Farrar, Straus and Giroux | location = New York }} * {{Citation | last = Shoemer | first=Karen | date=30 October 1992 | title=Some Alternative Boundaries Fall | newspaper=New York Times | url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9E0CE0D7123EF933A05753C1A964958260 }} * {{Citation | last = Weissman | first = Dick | year = 2003 | title = The music business : career opportunities and self-defense | isbn = 0-609-81013-8 | publisher = Three Rivers Press | location = New York }} {{Music industry}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Artists And Repertoire}} [[Category:Music industry]] [[Category:Occupations in music]] [[Category:Musical terminology]] [[Category:A&R people| ]]
