[[File:Melissa Bachman with Hunting Rifle (2).jpg|right|thumb|Melissa Bachman rifle hunting in 2014]]
'''Melissa Bachman''' (born 1984)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.melissabachman.com/|title=Melissa Bachman Online|last=Bachman|first=Melissa|accessdate=November 30, 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090415084129/http://www.melissabachman.com/|archivedate=2009-04-15}}</ref> is an American huntress, [[television producer|producer]], and [[television presenter|host]] of hunting television programs, currently of the cable television program ''Winchester Deadly Passion'' on the [[Sportsman Channel]], [[Pursuit Channel]], and [[Wild TV]].<ref name="Chaska">{{cite news|url=http://www.swnewsmedia.com/chaska_herald/straight-shooter/article_8d368400-3c7a-5b3c-9c99-0fe792a32b3e.html|title=Straight shooter|last=Francisco|first=Mollee|date=March 26, 2015|work=Chaska Herald|accessdate=November 10, 2015}}</ref><ref name=Winchester/> As a prominent female hunter, she has received personal online attacks as well as praise from supporters.
== Early life== Bachman was raised in [[Paynesville, Minnesota]]. Her parents, Dale and Karen Bachman, were both avid hunters who took her on their hunting trips since she was five years old.<ref name="SCTimes">{{cite news|url=http://www.sctimes.com/story/life/outdoors/2014/08/23/paynesville-woman-shares-hunting-passion-tv-show/14451123/|title=Paynesville woman shares hunting passion with TV show|last=Wessel|first=Ann|date=August 23, 2014|work=[[St. Cloud Times]]|accessdate=November 11, 2015}}</ref> She was not able to actually hunt until she was twelve, and had to do [[push-ups]] for over a year to develop the muscles to pull her {{convert|40|lb|adj=on}} bow.<ref name="Bow Adventures">{{cite news|url=http://issuu.com/bowadventures/docs/bow_adventures_summer_2012|title=20 Questions with Melissa Bachman|date=Summer 2012|work=Bow Adventures|publisher=[[Issuu]]|pages=28-33|accessdate=January 3, 2016}}</ref> Later her parents would sign a work permit so she could start high school at 10 a.m., after hunting in the mornings.<ref name="Quincy">{{cite news|url=http://www.whig.com/story/22206319/celebrity-hunter-helps-shooters-raise-money-for-boy-scouts|title=Celebrity hunter helps shooters raise money for Boy Scouts|last=Wilson|first=Doug|date=May 9, 2013|work=[[Quincy Herald-Whig]]|accessdate=January 4, 2016}}</ref>
She attended Paynesville Area High School where she competed in [[pole vault]] for the track team, setting school and section 5A records.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.paynesvillearea.com/news/sportsarticles/archives/060502/girlstrack060502.html|title=Bachman, Hess advance to state track|last=Meyer|first=Mandy|date=June 5, 2002|work=Paynesville Press|accessdate=November 30, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.paynesvillearea.com/news/sportsarticles/archives/061202/girlstrack061202.html|title=Hess wins third individual state title|last=Flanders|first=Ryan|date=June 12, 2002|work=Paynesville Press|accessdate=November 30, 2015}}</ref> She served as student representative to the [[Chamber of Commerce]] board, winning an Outstanding Young Person award, played [[saxophone]] in the [[concert band|concert]], [[pep band|pep]], and [[marching band]]s,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.paynesvillearea.com/news/headlinesarticles/archives/032702/bandcontest0327.html|title=Band members compete in solo/ensemble contest|last=Jacobson|first=Michael|date=March 27, 2002|work=Paynesville Press|accessdate=December 6, 2015}}</ref> was [[homecoming queen]], [[student council]] treasurer, a member of the [[National Honor Society]], [[captain (sports)|captain]] of track and speech teams, a [[Reader (liturgy)|lector]] in her [[Catholic]] church,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.paynesvillearea.com/news/headlinesarticles/archives/061301/queens.html|title=Five to vie for Miss Paynesville|last=Aagesen|first=Erin|date=June 13, 2001|work=Paynesville Press|accessdate=December 6, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.paynesvillearea.com/news/headlinesarticles/archives/011602/chamberbanquet.html|title=Chamber announces its awards at banquet|last=Jacobson|first=Michael|date=January 16, 2002|work=Paynesville Press|accessdate=December 6, 2015}}</ref> and earned the [[Gold Award (Girl Scouts of the USA)|Girl Scouts Gold Award]] by organizing younger [[Girl Scouts of the USA|Girl Scouts]] to interact with the elderly.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.paynesvillearea.com/news/headlinesarticles/archives/071702/0717bachman.html|title=Bachman earns Gold Award|last=Jones|first=Andy|date=July 17, 2002|work=Paynesville Press|accessdate=November 30, 2015}}</ref>
Bachman graduated Paynesville Area High School [[magna cum laude]] in 2002,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.paynesvillearea.com/news/headlinesarticles/archives/060502/graduation060502.html|title=Graduation will be held Sunday at PAHS|last=Jacobson|first=Michael|date=June 5, 2002|work=Paynesville Press|accessdate=December 6, 2015}}</ref> and attended [[St. Cloud State University]] with a double major in [[Spanish (language)|Spanish]] and [[Broadcast Journalism]].<ref name="Realtree">{{cite web|url=http://www.realtree.com/big-game-hunting/articles/behind-the-scenes-with-melissa-bachman|title=Behind the Scenes with Melissa Bachman|last=Reich|first=JJ|date=January 30, 2012|work=Big Game Hunting|publisher=Realtree|accessdate=November 10, 2015}}</ref> She survived a likely bout with [[viral meningitis]] during a 2004 summer Spanish immersion program in [[Costa Rica]].<ref name=Hanson>{{cite news|url=http://www.paynesvillearea.com/news/headlinesarticles/archives/110304/1103missybachman.html|title=Student survives serious illness while studying abroad|last=Hanson|first=Bonnie Jo|date=November 3, 2004|work=Paynesville Press|accessdate=November 11, 2015}}</ref> While pole vaulting in high school and college, Bachman would wrap her pole in [[camouflage]] to symbolize her passion for hunting.<ref name="Post-Bulletin">{{cite news|url=http://www.postbulletin.com/sports/outdoors/hunter-has-a-message-for-women/article_cd8e4fbf-22a3-5027-91ca-976d8f4f20be.html|title=Hunter has a message for women|last=John|first=Weiss|date=January 26, 2012|work=[[Post-Bulletin]]|accessdate=November 30, 2015}}</ref>
== Career == [[File:Melissa Bachman Bowhunting.jpg|left|thumb|Melissa Bachman bowhunting in 2015]] After graduating in 2006, Bachman sent out 76 video resumes without finding work, and had to take an unpaid internship with North American Media Group's ''[[North American Hunter]]'' Television in [[Minnetonka]], driving {{convert|150|mi}} round trip each day, and working nights as a waitress at a nightclub.<ref name="Chaska"/><ref name=SCTimes/> Four months later she was hired as a full time producer for the show. She progressed to camera work, first by giving on-camera [[archery]] tips that other hunters were unwilling to, and later by filming and editing many of her own hunts to be aired for free, including a [[bowhunting|bow hunt]] of a 202 inch Illinois [[White-tailed deer]].<ref name=SCTimes/><ref name="Realtree"/><ref name="Quincy"/> "Nobody turns down free work, I learned," she says.<ref name="Chaska"/> As a camera professional, she shot, produced, and edited the first season of [[Mark Kayser]]'s ''[[Extreme Pursuits]]'' program.<ref name="Realtree"/>
In 2010, Bachman left NAMG to found her own production company named Deadly Passion Productions. She edited and did post-production work for hunting television shows including ''[[Dangerous Game (TV series)|Dangerous Game]]'', created online and instructional videos, led seminars on hunting at sports shows, managed social media sites, and wrote magazine articles.<ref name="Realtree"/> In January 2012, she returned to ''North American Hunter'' as a host.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/HuntingClub/posts/178821142224271|title=She's Back: Melissa Bachman returns to the North American Hunting Club.|date=January 31, 2012|work=''[[North American Hunter]]''|publisher=[[Facebook]]|accessdate=January 4, 2016}}</ref><ref name="Post-Bulletin"/> Among her work for NAH was a five-day-a-week video series called ''"My Take" with Melissa Bachman'', that ran from February to August.<ref>{{cite tweet |author=Melissa Bachman|user=MelissaBachman |number=169089135456428032 |date=February 13, 2012 |title=Checkout my new web series called "My Take" that I'll be posting 5-days a week which revolves around hunting...|access-date=January 3, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite tweet |author=Melissa Bachman|user=MelissaBachman |number=238830654584926208 |date=August 23, 2012 |title="My Take" is going on hold and Melissa has a pretty good reason why! How does a new series with her on National...|access-date=January 3, 2016}}</ref><ref name="Bow Adventures"/>
In March 2012, Bachman took the world record for a [[red deer|red stag]] shot by a female archer in a [[New Zealand]] hunt.<ref name=SCTimes/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://portal.huntingclub.com/blogs/articletype/articleview/articleid/13988/the-story-bachmans-world-record-red-stag|title=World Record Red Stag|last=Bachman|first=Melissa|date=April 27, 2012|work=Hardcore Huntress with Melissa Bachman|publisher=[[North American Hunter]]|accessdate=November 30, 2015}}</ref> The hunt was aired both on ''"My Take"'' and on ''Winchester Deadly Passion''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GjxL6cRiTAI&feature=youtu.be|title="My Take" with Melissa Bachman: World-Record Red Stag Bow Kill|date=May 4, 2012|work=''[[North American Hunter]]''|publisher=[[YouTube]]|accessdate=January 4, 2016}}</ref><ref name=Stag>{{cite web|url=https://vimeo.com/86256910|title=New Zealand World Record Stag - Winchester Deadly Passion|last=Bachman|first=Melissa|date=February 9, 2014|work=[[Vimeo]]|accessdate=November 30, 2015}}</ref>
[[Image:Melissa Bachman with SureShot Jewelry necklace.jpg|right|thumb|upright|Melissa Bachman with SureShot Jewelry ammunition based necklace in 2015.]] The ''Winchester Deadly Passion'' program, also produced by North American Media Group, began airing in July 2012 on the [[Pursuit Channel]],<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.theoutdoorwire.com/story/1341558615vkhj53nau36|title=North America Media Group Unveils Winchester Deadly Passion|work=The Outdoor Wire|date=July 6, 2012|accessdate=November 11, 2015}}</ref> and was picked up by the [[Sportsman Channel]] for its third season, July 2014.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ammoland.com/2014/07/winchester-deadly-passion-with-melissa-bachman-debuts-this-week/|title=Winchester Deadly Passion with Melissa Bachman Debuts This Week|last=Scheuermann|first=Michelle|date=July 2, 2014|work=Ammoland Shooting Sports News|accessdate=January 4, 2016}}</ref> It is named after and sponsored by [[Winchester Ammunition]]. In it, Melissa Bachman is filmed traveling the world to hunt animals using rifle, bow, or shotgun.<ref name="Winchester">{{cite web|url=http://www.winchester.com/livin-the-life/tv-series/Pages/Winchester-Deadly-Passion.aspx|title=Winchester Deadly Passion TV Series|publisher=[[Winchester Ammunition]]|accessdate=January 3, 2016}}</ref> Bachman stars in, produces, and edits the program herself. She works around 200 days a year in the field, switching between two cameramen who need more time off.<ref name=SCTimes/> In 2014, the program came out with a clothing line,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ammoland.com/2014/08/deadly-passion-apparel-now-available/|title=Deadly Passion Apparel Now Available|last=Scheuermann|first=Michelle|date=August 27, 2014|work=AmmoLand Shooting Sports News|accessdate=January 3, 2016}}</ref> and in 2015, Bachman sponsored an ammunition based jewelry line.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ammoland.com/2015/05/melissa-bachman-teams-up-with-sureshot-jewelry/|title=Melissa Bachman Teams Up with SureShot™ Jewelry|last=Scheuermann|first=Michelle|date=May 11, 2015|work=AmmoLand Shooting Sports News|accessdate=January 3, 2016}}</ref>
Bachman struggles for an answer when asked about her life outside TV programs and hunting.<ref name="Chaska"/> "I can't even keep a plant alive — that's how little I'm home," she says.<ref name="SCTimes"/>
== Controversies over trophy hunting == On August 30, 2012, the [[National Geographic Channel]] were planning Bachman to be one of their contestants for the show that would become [[Ultimate Survival Alaska]], until a [[Change.org]] petition to exclude her because of her hunting background received 13,000 signatures in under 24 hours.<ref name="Hollywood">{{cite news|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/national-geographic-channel-animal-rights-melissa-bachman-ultimate-survivor-alaska-367238|title=National Geographic Channel Drops Survivalist Over Animal Rights Complaints|last=Goldberg|first=Lesley|date=August 31, 2012|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|accessdate=November 10, 2015}}</ref> National Geographic's statement, in three [[Twitter]] posts, said she was eliminated because hunting was not the focus of the show.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/09/03/arts/television/national-geographic-takes-hunter-off-tv-show.html?_r=0|title=National Geographic Takes Hunter Off TV Show|last=Kepler|first=Adam W.|date=September 2, 2012|work=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=December 7, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/NatGeoChannel/status/241290996325953536|title="Upon further reflection, we plan to eliminate one of the survivalists from the ensemble cast, Melissa Bachman…"|last=Nat Geo Channel|date=August 30, 2012|work=[[Twitter]]|accessdate=December 7, 2015}}</ref> Conservationist Tim Martell, who launched the petition, had previously launched a Facebook campaign against [[Rosie O'Donnell]] for appearing with a [[hammerhead shark]] she had caught. Martell stated he did not oppose all hunting, primarily [[trophy hunting]], which he considered wasteful.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.yahoo.com/blogs/the-sideshow/national-geographic-channel-removes-hardcore-huntress-show-online-214545958.html|title=National Geographic Channel removes ‘hardcore huntress’ from show after online protest goes viral|last=Pfeiffer|first=Eric|date=August 31, 2012|work=[[Yahoo! News]]|accessdate=December 7, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.realtree.com/big-game-hunting/articles/on-melissa-bachman-nat-geo-tim-martell-and-anti-hunters|title=On Melissa Bachman, Nat Geo, Tim Martell and Anti-Hunters|last=Brantley|first=Will|date=September 12, 2012|work=Big Game Hunting|publisher=Realtree|accessdate=December 7, 2015}}</ref>
In November 2013, Bachman posted a photograph of herself smiling by the body of a lion, captioned "An incredible day hunting in [[South Africa]]! Stalked inside 60-yards on this beautiful male lion... what a hunt!" to her [[Twitter]] and [[Facebook]] accounts.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/nov/15/hunter-melissa-bachman-picture-lion-south-africa|title=US hunter criticised over picture with dead lion in South Africa|last=Smith|first=David|date=November 15, 2013|work=[[The Guardian]]|accessdate=December 29, 2015}}</ref> The photo quickly drew Internet outrage, including multiple wishes for her death,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/melissa-bachman-twitter-fury-death-wishes-vicious-insults-follow-south-african-lion-hunt-1475462|title=Melissa Bachman Twitter Fury: Death Wishes, Vicious Insults Follow South African Lion Hunt|last=Zara|first=Christopher|date=November 18, 2013|work=[[International Business Times]]|accessdate=December 29, 2015}}</ref> comedian and animal welfare activist [[Ricky Gervais]] re-tweeting Bachman's message while adding "spot the typo", and an online petition from a [[Cape Town]] resident calling on the South African government to eject her from the country,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ctvnews.ca/world/what-was-she-thinking-tv-host-posts-photo-of-lion-kill-on-safari-1.1547598|title=What was she thinking? TV host Melissa Bachman posts photo of lion kill while on African safari|publisher=[[CTV News]]|last=Leung|first=Marlene|date=November 17, 2013|accessdate=December 29, 2015}}</ref> which gathered hundreds of thousands of signatures.<ref name=Monitor/> In reaction, Bachman temporarily deactivated her public Facebook and Twitter accounts.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/northamerica/usa/10453255/TV-presenter-causes-outrage-after-posing-with-lion-she-killed.html|title=TV presenter causes outrage after posing with lion she killed - Telegraph|last=Swaine|first=Jon|date=November 15, 2013|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|accessdate=December 29, 2015}}</ref> Many of the death threats instead went to an unrelated person with a similar name.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/melissa-bachman-twitter-hunters-bully-wrong-target-terrified-grad-student-harassed-threatened|title=Melissa Bachman Twitter Hunters Bully Wrong Target: Terrified Grad Student Harassed, Threatened In Mistaken Identity|last=Zara|first=Christopher|date=November 20, 2013|work=[[International Business Times]]|accessdate=December 29, 2015}}</ref> The Maroi Conservancy, which facilitated the hunt through another outfitter in [[Zeerust]],<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2013/11/131119-melissa-bachman-lion-hunt-photo-conservation-animals/|title=Lion Hunt Photo Touches Off Heated Conservation Debate|last=Howard|first=Brian Clark|date=November 21, 2013|work=[[National Geographic Society]]|accessdate=December 29, 2015}}</ref> defended the hunt, stating it was both legal and ethical, and that food and funds from these kinds of hunts go to the struggling local community.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://abcnews.go.com/US/hunting-star-stirs-outrage-posting-photo-dead-lion/story?id=20911636|title=Hunting Star Stirs Outrage After Posting Photo of Dead Lion|publisher=[[ABC News]]|last=Mohney|first=Gillian|date=November 16, 2013|accessdate=December 29, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/africa/us-tv-presenter-melissa-bachman-blasted-over-smiling-photo-with-lion-she-stalked-and-killed-8944363.html|title=Melissa Bachman blasted over smiling photo with lion she 'stalked and killed' |last=Jivanda|first=Tomas|date=November 16, 2013|work=[[The Independent]]|accessdate=December 29, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/11/18/lion-hunt-melissa-bachman-south-africa-photo_n_4297780.html|title=Lion-Hunting U.S. TV Host Has South Africa In An Uproar|last=Grenoble|first=Ryan|date=November 18, 2013|work=[[The Huffington Post]]|accessdate=December 29, 2015}}</ref> International commentators claimed that the online anger directed at Bachman was extraordinary, sexist, and misogynist,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymaverick.co.za/article/2013-11-18-analysis-melissa-bachman-and-online-misogyny|title=Analysis: Melissa Bachman and online misogyny|last=Davis|first=Rebecca|date=November 18, 2013|work=[[Daily Maverick]]|accessdate=December 29, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://vagendamagazine.com/2013/11/is-melissa-bachman-a-fugly-bitch-for-killing-a-lion/|title=Is Melissa Bachman A Fugly Bitch For Killing A Lion?|date=November 27, 2013|work=[[The Vagenda]]|accessdate=January 4, 2016}}</ref> and that evidence showed that banning hunting drives species extinct much more than controlled hunts do.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymaverick.co.za/opinionista/2013-11-19-in-defence-of-a-lion-killer|title=In defence of a lion killer|last=Vegter|first=Ivo|date=November 19, 2013|work=[[Daily Maverick]]|accessdate=December 29, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2013/nov/23/melissa-bachman-lion-hunting-internet-backlash|title=Lion hunter Melissa Bachman isn't the problem. South African law is|last=Moosa|first=Tauriq|date=November 23, 2013|work=[[The Guardian]]|accessdate=January 4, 2016}}</ref> At the time of the hunt, African lions were not listed as endangered under the United States [[Endangered Species Act]], though their status was under reassessment and debate.<ref name=Monitor>{{cite news|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/Environment/2013/1121/Melissa-Bachman-s-African-lion-hunt-draws-anger|title=Melissa Bachman's African lion hunt draws anger|last=Pak-Harvey|first=Amelia|date=November 21, 2013|work=[[The Christian Science Monitor]]|accessdate=December 29, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fws.gov/news/ShowNews.cfm?ID=0C3DDACA-E528-1568-54FE2494D3A77B74|title=U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service Initiates Review of African Lion Under the Endangered Species Act|date=November 27, 2012|work=Press Release|publisher=U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service|accessdate=January 19, 2016}}</ref>
Bachman did not directly comment in response to the controversies, though she has said that [[hate mail]] from anti-hunters was one thing she "could do without".<ref name="Bow Adventures"/> In 2015, she stated, "No response at all seems to be the best. It doesn’t matter what you say, or how you say it, some people will always disagree and attack."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://huntinglife.com/melissa-bachman-talks-the-hunting-life/|title=Melissa Bachman talks the Hunting Life|last=Paulson|first=Kevin|date=June 26, 2015|work=Hunting Life|accessdate=December 29, 2015}}</ref>

{{EngvarB|date=August 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}} {{Infobox artist | bgcolour = #6495ED | name = Michael Dickinson | image = Michael Dickinson.jpg | imagesize = 180 px | caption = Michael Dickinson | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth-date|1950}} | birth_place = [[Durham, England|Durham]], England | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = British | field = [[Collage]] | training = | movement = [[Stuckism]] | works = ''Tyrant's Pants'', ''Best in Show'', ''Good Boy'' | patrons = | influenced by = | influenced = | awards = }} '''Michael Dickinson''' (born 1950, [[Durham, England|Durham]]) is an English artist known for his work in Turkey, who works with political and satirical [[collage]]s. In 2008, he was prosecuted for a collage of the Turkish prime minister, but acquitted.<ref name=tait>Tait, Robert. [https://www.theguardian.com/world/2008/sep/26/turkey.humanrights "Turkish court acquits British artist over portraying PM as US poodle"], ''[[The Guardian]]'', 26 September 2008. Retrieved 26 September 2008.</ref> He is also a member of the international [[art movement]] [[Stuckism]].<ref name=tait/>
==Life and work== Michael Dickinson was born in [[Durham, England|Durham]], England, and spent most of his early years in [[Kuwait]], where his father was an employee of the [[Kuwait Oil Company]] and where he attended the Anglo-American School.<ref name=timessatire>Alberge, Dalya and Erdem, Suna (2006). [http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/europe/article675651.ece Satire that could land British artist in a Turkish jail], ''[[The Times]]'', 17 June 2006. Retrieved 17 August 2007.</ref> He later attended [[Fyling Hall]] school in [[Yorkshire]]. He lives and works as an English teacher in Istanbul. He is the founder of the Istanbul branch of the [[Stuckism|Stuckist]] art movement,<ref>[http://www.stuckism.com/world.html#Turkey "Stuckist groups"], stuckism.com. Retrieved 4 April 2008.</ref> and also a writer, playwright and actor.
===Collage banned by Tripod===
In May 2005, Dickinson's web site, "The Carnival of Chaos", was blanked and he was informed by the host Tripod (a member of the [[Lycos]] group), "You are no longer an authorized member of Tripod. You have been removed because your web site violated our Terms of Service."<ref name=banned>[http://www.stuckism.com/Dickinson/Index.html "The Carnival of Chaos banned"], stuckism.com. Retrieved 12 June 2006.</ref> This occurred after he had posted a collage, ''Tyrant's Pants'', showing President Bush in his underpants with a cruise missile coming out of his rear and a [[swastika]] on his right buttock.<ref name=tait/><ref name=banned/>
[[File:Tyrant's-Pants.jpg|thumb|upright|''Tyrant's Pants'' collage by Michael Dickinson showing President Bush]] The collage was a response to a photo which had appeared with the headline "Tyrant's in his pants" on the front page of the British tabloid newspaper ''[[The Sun (United Kingdom)|The Sun]]'', showing captive [[Saddam Hussein]] in underpants.<ref name=banned/>
===Turkish court case===
In June 2006, [[Istanbul]] police removed one of Dickinson's collages from a show in the city organised by the Global Peace and Justice Coalition.<ref name=timessatire/> Dickinson states that he hung his work in the show unknown to the organisers.<ref name=guardianbriton>Birch, Nicholas. [http://arts.guardian.co.uk/news/story/0,,1871134,00.html "Briton charged over 'insult' to Turkish PM"], ''[[The Guardian]]'', 13 September 2006. Retrieved 2 September 2007.</ref> The collage showed the Turkish Prime Minister [[Tayyip Erdoğan]] as a dog being presented with a rosette by [[George W. Bush|President Bush]] in a pet show.<ref name=timessatire/> He was informed by Turkish authorities that he would be prosecuted for "insulting the Prime Minister's dignity"; the charge carries a sentence of one to three years.<ref name=blairasked>[http://www.timesonline.co.uk/article/0,,2087-2220955,00.html "Blair asked to help artist facing jail"] ''[[The Sunday Times]]'', 11 June 2006. Retrieved 12 June 2006.</ref>
[[File:Michael Dickinson. Best in Show.jpg|thumb|left|''Best in Show'' collage by Michael Dickinson showing Turkish Prime Minister [[Tayyip Erdoğan]] as a dog given a rosette by US President George Bush]] ''[[The Times]]'' said: "The case could greatly embarrass Turkey and Britain, for it raises questions about Turkey’s human rights record as it seeks EU membership, with Tony Blair’s backing."<ref name=timessatire/> [[Charles Thomson (artist)|Charles Thomson]], co-founder of the Stuckist movement, wrote to British Prime Minister [[Tony Blair]] asking for his intervention:<ref name=vatan>[http://www.vatanim.com.tr/root.vatan?exec=haberdetay&tarih=12.06.2006&Newsid=79736&Categoryid=7 "Erdoğan'ı kızdıran kolaj için Blair devreye girdi"] ''Vatan'' (in Turkish) online, 12 June 2006. Retrieved 12 June 2006.</ref> "It is intolerable that a country applying for EU membership should censor freedom of political comment in this way. I trust you will communicate your strongest condemnation and ask for this case to be abandoned immediately. I ask for your assurance that you will oppose Turkish EU membership in the strongest terms, until Turkey adopts the attitudes of the civilised world towards human rights."<ref name=stuckistartist>[http://www.stuckism.com/Dickinson/Turkey.html "Blair asked to intervene as Stuckist artist faces 3 years jail in Turkey for this collage"] stuckism.com. Retrieved 12 June 2006</ref> Dickinson said: "It’s such an Alice in Wonderland feeling. The law is so absurd ... This law exists in Turkey about insulting 'Turkishness' or the State. You’re not allowed to state your opinion."<ref name=timessatire/>
In September 2006, Dickinson attended the trial of Erkan Kara, organiser of the Global Peace and Justice Coalition show, charged with insulting behaviour for exhibiting Dickinson's work. The prosecutor described Dickinson as "ill-intentioned", but declined to bring a case because of "lack of evidence".<ref name=guardianbriton/> Hasan Gungor of the Istanbul-based group, Initiative for Freedom of Speech, attributed this to fear of international news, when the [[European Union]] has concerns over freedom of speech in Turkey.<ref name=guardianbriton/>
[[File:Michael Dickinson. Good Boy.jpg|thumb|''Good Boy'' by Michael Dickinson. He was prosecuted for its display.]] Members of Global Peace and Justic Coalition remonstrated with Dickinson for distracting attention from their anti-[[Iraq War]] cause, and he then held up another collage showing Erdogan as a dog with a lead of the [[Flag of the United States|stars and stripes]]; he was arrested and charged with insulting the Turkish prime minister's dignity<ref name=guardianbriton/> with a trial date scheduled for October 2007.<ref>Duff, Oliver. [http://news.independent.co.uk/people/pandora/article2542390.ece "Stuck in legal limbo"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070817030632/http://news.independent.co.uk/people/pandora/article2542390.ece |date=17 August 2007 }}, ''[[The Independent]]'', 15 May 2007. Retrieved 2 September 2007.</ref> He was then held for ten days, three in prison and seven in the Detention Centre for Foreigners.<ref>Dickinson, Michael. [http://www.counterpunch.org/dickinson11042006.html "A prison diary: Watching the guards"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070824185245/http://www.counterpunch.org/dickinson11042006.html |date=24 August 2007 }}, counterpunch.org, 4 November 2006. Retrieved 2 September 2007.</ref> During his transfer between facilities, he attempted to escape, but was shot at by a policeman, who recaptured him.<ref>Dickinson, Michael. [http://www.counterpunch.org/dickinson09302006.html "Extract from a diary in Turkish police custody: My escape attempt in prison transfer"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070827192655/http://www.counterpunch.org/dickinson09302006.html |date=27 August 2007 }}, counterpunch.org, 15 September 2006. Retrieved 2 September 2007.</ref>
In July 2007, Dickinson's collages were displayed at the [[A Gallery]], London, in the Stuckist show ''I Won't Have Sex with You as long as We're Married''.<ref>[http://www.stuckism.com/AGalleryJuly07/IndexShow.html "I won't have sex with you as long as we're married"], stuckism.com. Retrieved 2 September 2007. Photos of the collages in the A Gallery show.</ref>
On 25 September 2008, he was acquitted of any crime, the judge ruling that although there were "some insulting elements" in his collage, it fell "within the limits of criticism".<ref name=tait/> The case has favourable implications for Turkey's relationship with the [[European Union]], which had called for an improvement of its human rights record.<ref name=tait/> Dickinson said, "I am lucky to be acquitted. There are still artists in Turkey facing prosecution and being sentenced for their opinions."<ref name=tait/>
In June 2009, Dickinson fled Turkey for his native country, Britain, after learning that his acquittal had been overturned. Unable to find work, he returned to Istanbul soon after. In January 2010, a Turkish court convicted Dickinson of mocking the Turkish prime minister and levied a fine. Refusing to pay the fine as a matter of principle, Dickinson faces up to two years in prison.<ref>BBC News. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/england/wear/8483479.stm "Artist fined for art mocking Turkey's prime minister"], 27 January 2010. Retrieved 31 January 2010.</ref> His final sentencing will occur at a trial on 9 March 2010.
Dickinson's application for a residence permit was refused due to his 2010 conviction, but he remained in the country after the expiry of his tourist visa. He was arrested in October 2013 for shouting [[Gezi Park]]-related slogans at police, and detained after his expired visa was discovered. He was deported after some days (and banned from returning for five years), choosing to go to Barcelona rather than his native Britain.<ref>Michael Dickinson, ''CounterPunch'', 1 November 2013, [http://www.counterpunch.org/2013/11/01/tossed-out-of-turkey-after-twenty-seven-years/ Tossed Out Of Turkey After Twenty Seven Years]</ref>
==See also== *[[Article 301 (Turkish penal code)]] *[[Censorship in Turkey]] *[[Human rights in Turkey]] *[[Human rights in Europe]] *[[International Freedom of Expression Exchange]] *[[List of prosecuted Turkish writers]] *[[Culture of Turkey]] *[[Stuckism]] *[[Stuckist demonstrations]] *[[Böhmermann affair]]

{{Infobox company | name = Newbridge Silverware | foundation = 1934<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newbridgesilverware.com/about/us|website=Newbridge Silverware|accessdate=12 August 2014}}</ref> | key_people = [[William Doyle (Irish businessman)|William Doyle]] (CEO) | location = [[Newbridge, County Kildare]], [[Republic of Ireland]] | coordinates = | homepage = {{URL|www.newbridgesilverware.com}} }} Designer and producer of jewellery, homeware and giftware products and it is this unique history of craftsmanship and experience, combined with a contemporary and fresh attitude to design, that puts Newbridge Silverware on the cutting edge of modern living.
==Products== * Giftware * Silver-Plated / E.P.N.S. Cutlery * Kitchenware * Stainless Steel Cutlery * Christmas * Jewellery * Earthenware * Cookware * Cutlery * Entertainment
==Location== The main store is located in [[Newbridge, County Kildare]] and consists of [http://www.newbridgesilverware.com/visit_us/visitors_centre The Visitor Centre and the Newbridge Showrooms], as well as the [http://www.newbridgesilverware.com/visit_us/museum Museum of Style Icons] and the [http://www.newbridgesilverware.com/visit_us/restaurant Café Carleton]. However, Newbridge Silverware products are sold worldwide in a large number of stores. The entire catalog is also available to shop online from the company's online store with free delivery to Ireland and the U.K. at [http://www.NewbridgeSilverware.com www.NewbridgeSilverware.com]
==The Museum of Style Icons== The store in Newbridge contains an upstairs [http://www.newbridgesilverware.com/visit_us/museum Museum of Style Icons] (MOSI), such as [[Audrey Hepburn]] and [[Marilyn Monroe]]. The museum contains clothes and artefacts associated with such stars. The most spectacular piece on display is the hot-pink, silk cocktail dress worn by Audrey Hepburn as [[Holly Golightly (character)|Holly Golightly]] in [[Breakfast at Tiffany's (film)|Breakfast at Tiffany's]] in 1961. The dress was acquired by Newbridge Silverware's CEO, Mr. [[William Doyle (Irish businessman)|William Doyle]], for $160,000.

{{refimprove|date=December 2009}} [[File:Student from UNY reading short story by Evi Idawati 2015-06-08 06.jpg|thumb|A student of [[Yogyakarta State University]] performing a dramatic reading of a short story]] '''Oral Interpretation''' is a dramatic art, also commonly called "interpretive reading" and "dramatic reading", though these terms are more conservative and restrictive. In certain applications, oral interpretation is also a theatre art – as in reader's theatre, in which a work of literature is performed with manuscripts in hand or, more traditionally, using stools and music stands; and especially chamber theatre, which dispenses with manuscripts and uses what may be described as essentialist costuming and stage lighting, and suggestive scenery.
The term is succinctly defined by [[Paul Campbel]]l (''The Speaking and Speakers of Literature''; Dickinson, 1967) as the "oralization of literature"; or more eloquently, if less intelligibly, by Charlotte Lee and Timothy Gura (''Oral Interpretation''; Houghton-Mifflin, 1997) as "the art of communicating to an audience a work of literary art in its intellectual, emotional, and aesthetic entirety". Historically essential to Charlotte Lee's definition of oral interpretation is the fact the performer is "reading from a manuscript". This perspective, once the majority view, has long since become the minority opinion on the question; so that whether one is or is not reading from a manuscript, the art retains the same name.
Voice and movement technique is ''opsis'' ("spectacle") while oral interpretation is, conceptually, ''melopoiia'' ("music technique").
Because oral interpretation is an essential dramatic element in all performance art (even dance, in which the oral element is most typically a silent element), all actors, singers, storytellers, etc., are ''interpreters'' – but not all interpreters are necessarily actors, or singers, or storytellers, and so on. When, for example, the writer [[David Sedaris]] reads one of his stories on stage, or when [[Leonard Cohen]] performs one of his lyric poems, they are both engaged in the art of oral interpretation. But Sedaris is no actor, and even Cohen himself would say that ''he'' is no singer.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cohencentric.com/2015/06/22/rarely-viewed-video-leonard-cohen-on-his-atrocious-voice-dylan-lead-belly-ice-t-songwriting-love-wheres-the-beef/|title=1992 Video: Leonard Cohen On His Atrocious Voice, Dylan, Ice-T, Songwriting, Love & Where's The Beef|date=22 June 2015|work=cohencentric.com}}</ref>
In the United States, there is a historic and purely academic argument as to whether oral interpretation and drama/theatre performance are different names for the same thing or whether they are completely different art forms. This argument is almost exclusively found at colleges and universities whose theatre programs evolved in departments historically or currently called "English and Speech", "Speech and Dramatic Arts" or "Communication and Theatre Arts". The argument is rarely heard in theatre programs that did not evolve out of English and/or Speech Communication departments, such as those associated with schools/colleges of music.
In high schools across the United States, Oral Interpretation is a very highly valued competition event, particularly in the mid-western states, such as Nebraska, Iowa, and South Dakota. Students select a work of literature, make a cutting of the literature to fit a time limit of 10 minutes, and perform it in several rounds at tournaments across their state. The piece must be from a published, worthwhile piece of literature, with the exception of Readers Theatre. The categories of said event are as follows: * Serious Prose—Interpretation of a work of prose literature with a serious basis. Single-person event. * Humorous Interp—Interpretation of any published work of comedic literature. Single-person event * Dramatic Interp—Interpretation of a dramatic play with a serious nature. Single-person event. * Poetry—Interpretation of a published work of poetry. Single-person event. * Non-Original Oratory—Interpretation of an oratorical speech that has been previously delivered. Single-person event. * Duo Interpretation—Interpretation of a piece of literature where two Interpers are involved. The pair may not look at nor touch each other, and must deliver the piece in the direction of the audience. This category has the most stringent rules. * Readers Theatre—A theatrical interpretation performance where 3-6 people participate. They may perform an original piece, or they may take a cutting from a work of literature. This category has the least amount of rules.

revision.text:
{{Refimprove|date=October 2011}} [[File:Prince Salim (the future Jahangir) and his legendary illicit love.jpg|thumb|Jahangir and [[Anarkali]].]] {{Culture of Pakistan}}
[[Pakistan]] has a wide variety of [[folklore]], mostly circulated regionally. However, certain tales have related variants in other regions of the country or in [[neighbouring]] [[countries]]. ''Pakistani [[mythology]]'' here means the myths and sacred narratives of the culturally and linguistically [[Indo-Iranians|related groups of ancient peoples]] who inhabited the region of Pakistan and its borderlands.
==Music== {{Main article|Pakistani folk music}}
== Provincial folklore == The provinces of Pakistan are known by the love stories in their folklore that have been immortalized by singers, reciters and storytellers of the regions.
=== Sindhi folklore === {{Main article|Sindhi folklore}} '''Sindhi folklore''' ({{lang-sd|''' لوڪ ادب'''}}) is the [[folklore|folk]] tradition which has developed in Sindh over a number of centuries.Sindh abounds with folklore, in all forms, and colors from such obvious manifestations as the traditional [[Watayo Faqir]] tales, the legend of ''Moriro'', epic tale of [[Dodo Soomro|Dodo Chanesar]], to the heroic character of [[Marui]] which distinguishes it among the contemporary folklores of the region. The love story of [[Sassui Punhun|Sassui]], who pines for her lover Punhu, is known and sung in every Sindhi settlement. Other examples of the folklore of Sindh include the stories of Umar Marui and Suhuni Mehar.<ref>Kalyan Adwani, ed. ''[[Shah Jo Risalo]]''. [[Jamshoro]]: Sindhi Adabi Board, 2002.</ref>
Sindhi folk Singers and women play a vital role to transmit the Sindhi folklore. They sang the [[Sindhi folk tales|folktales of Sindh]] in songs with passion in every village of Sindh.
Sindhi folklore has been compiled in a series of forty volumes under [[Sindhi Adabi Board]]'s project of '''Folklore and Literature'''.This valuable project was accomplished by noted sindhi scholar [[Nabi Bux Khan Baloch|Dr.Nabi Bux Baloch]].The material for the project has been collected both from the oral traditions village folks and the written record. This folklore series deals with diverse segments Sindhi folklore and literature i.e. Fables and Fairy-tales, pseudo-historical Romances, Folk-poetry, Folk songs, Proverbs, Riddles etc.
=== Balochi folklore === [[Balochi language|Balochi]] folklore is alive with the love stories of [[Hani and Sheh Mureed|Hani and Shah Murad Chakar]], [[Shahdad and Mahnaz]], [[Lallah and Granaz]], [[Bebarg and Granaz]], and [[Mast and Sammo]], among others. The war tales of the [[Baloch people|Baloch]] are equally stirring. The ''[[chap (dance)|chap]]'', a [[Baloch people|Baloch]] style of dancing, has a curious rhythm distinguished by an inertial back sway with every forward step. Baloch music has a unique flavour of its own.
=== Kashmiri folklore === [[Kashmiri language|Kashmiri]] regions in the north are equally rich in folklore.
=== Pakhtun folklore === In the [[Pukhtun]] areas of the northwest, the [[Khyber Pakhtunkhwa|North-West Frontier Province]] is the home of energetic warlike dancers, the most prominent being the Khattak dance, which bears the name of the tribe that dances it. The romantic tale of [[Adam Khan And Durkhanai|Adam Khan]] and Durkhanai features a lute player (''[[rabab]]'') whose music earns the love of a beautiful girl, although she hasn't seen him yet.
=== Punjabi folklore === {{Main article|Punjabi folklore}} Many folk tales from [[Punjab region|Punjab]] have been disseminated worldwide by the [[Punjabi diaspora]], especially in the [[United Kingdom|UK]] and United States. The tale of two lovers, [[Heer Ranjha|Heer]] and Ranjha, is based in the [[Pakistan]]i part of the [[Punjab (Pakistan)|Punjab]], in a city called [[Jhang]]. Today it is celebrated in songs, movies, theatre, and quotations. One may call a romantic person a Ranjha, meaning he is a devoted lover. Similarly a girl in love may be called "Heer." Apart from the epic of Hir and Ranjha, the Punjab has a rich tradition of ballads, folk tales, folk music and dance. The folklore of the Potohar Plateau of the north shows a local variant, while the lush green irrigated agriculture of the central plains is home to more sophisticated forms of folklore. The oldest living urban centre of Multan in the south is home to gentler forms of music and dance.
=== Saraiki folklore === [[Saraiki language|Saraiki]] areas in the south are equally rich in folklore.
== External folklore == {{Disputed|date=October 2012}}
The [[Muslim]] high culture of [[Pakistan]] and rest of [[South Asia]] emphasizes [[Arab culture|Arabic]], [[Persian culture|Persian]] and [[Turkic peoples|Turkic]] culture. [[Islamic mythology]] and is part of Pakistans folklore, as Islamic religion dominates Pakistan since it was imposed by the pan-Islamism colonialists of the Ottoman Empire.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://webs.bcp.org/sites/vcleary/modernworldhistorytextbook/imperialism/section_3/turningpoint2.html|title=The Turning Point in Asia: Early Modern European and Asian Empires (1500-1800)|last=Cleary|first=Vern|website=webs.bcp.org|access-date=2017-01-08}}</ref> The [[Shahnameh]], ''[[One Thousand and One Nights]]'' and ''[[Sinbad the Sailor]]'' were part of the education of children in what is now Pakistan before English education was imposed by the British colonialism.
== See also == * [[Indo-Iranian mythology|Indo-Iranic mythology]] * [[Adam Khan and Durkhanai]] * [[Alam Lohar]] * [[Arabian mythology]] * [[Gulistan of Sa'di]] * [[Hani and Sheh Mureed]] * [[Hatim al-Tai]] * [[Heer Ranjha]] * [[Islamic mythology]] * [[Layla and Majnun]] * [[LiLa Chanesar]] * [[Magic carpet]] * [[Mirza Sahiba]] * [[Momal Rano]] * [[Nasrudin|Mullah Nasreddin]] * [[Noori Jam Tamachi]] * [[One Thousand and One Nights]] * [[Paristan]] * [[Peri]] * [[Prince Saiful Malook and Badri Jamala]] * [[Punjabi Kisse]] * [[Sassi Punnun]] * [[Shah Jo Risalo]] * [[Shahnameh]] * [[Sinbad the Sailor]] * [[Sohni Mahiwal]] * [[The Tale of the Four Dervishes]] * [[Yusuf and Zulaikha]] * [[Yusuf Khan and Sherbano]] * [[Iranian mythology|Iranic mythology]] * [[Indo-Aryan mythology]]

{{Infobox Artwork | image_file= Lubo Kristek,Requiem für die Mobiltelephone.jpg | backcolor=#FBF5DF | painting_alignment=right | image_size=300px | title= Requiem for Mobile Telephones | artist=[[Lubo Kristek]] | year= 2007–2010 | medium=interactive [[Assemblage (art)|assemblage]] | height_metric=300 | width_metric=210 | length_metric=80 | metric_unit=cm | city= | museum= }} '''Requiem for Mobile Telephones'''Published in Neunzert 2008, p. 39. is an interactive [[Assemblage (art)|assemblage]]Putová 2013, p. 21. of the [[performance art|performance artist]] [[Lubo Kristek]] and also a series of his [[happening]]s. The artist started his happening series in 2007 to protest against the addictions to new technologies. He asked the audience to give up their mobile phones and use them to create an assemblage.Putová 2013, p. 121. == Background == The first action was held in the city of [[Znojmo]]. The spectators sewed the mobile phones directly on to the artist wearing a jacket with a train (the jacket then became the basis for new assemblage). The second happening took place in public area – on the pavement of Mariahilfer Straße in [[Vienna]] in 2007. Kristek who likes to remove the barriers between art and reality, deliberately got with his action in the way of passers-by to pull them out of their stereotype and to force them adopt an attitude. The artist dipped the balerina’s [[pointe shoe]]s into the paint and let her dance on a blank canvas.Putová 2013, p. 77. The pointe shoes also became part of the assemblage afterwards. Then he invited school pupils and passers-by to help to create the new assemblage, to paint and sew more mobile phones on to it. Art and life merged in the [[avant-garde]] sense. The assemblage travelled to an exhibition at the Barockschloß Riegersburg, today [[Schloss Ruegers]] (2007). The artist continued to travel with his mission to other states. With each happening interaction the assemblage changed its shape. In 2008, the happening series continued in the Neues Stadtmuseum, [[Landsberg am Lech]]. It was part of the retrospective exhibition of the works by Lubo Kristek titled ''Third Eye of Distant Communication''.{{cite web|first=Manuela|last=Rieger|url=http://www.augsburger-allgemeine.de/landsberg/Kunst-zum-Nachdenken-id3697011.html|title=Kunst zum Nachdenken|website=Augsburger Algemeine|publisher=|date=12 May 2008|access-date=16 August 2018|language=de}} {{Quote|In the happening a new character appeared, Temptation (played by the prima ballerina of the Brno National Theatre Jana Přibylová), who gives the spectators electronic devices from a pink sack and who suddenly turnes into the devil). In one of the last scenes, this character toys with a representation of human fate – a black figurine – which she throws to the ground as soon as she tires of her plaything. At the end of the happening, Kristek carried the pink sack full of electronic refuse to the altar of the Landsberg Church of the Holy Cross. In this way, he emphasised the sharp contrast between our ancestors´ legacy and what will remain after the current epoch.Putová 2018, [http://glyptotheque.com/index.php/meeting-point/requiem-for-mobile-telephones Chapter: Meeting place – Requiem for Mobile Telephones]}} The following happening took place in a Polish city of [[Sucha Beskidzka]] in 2010. According to Kristek, the relationship of contemporary society to the mobile telephone bears the traits of a [[cult]] or even a pathological dependency. Therefore he places this “modern god” on the altar (with the inscription Rest in Peace) and lets a giant triple-breasted angel to drill it through. The participants of the happening actively contribute to the act of [[sacrifice|sacrificing]] the mobile phones. {{Quote|The artist destroys the mobiles in the happenings. He disposes of them like refuse, but at the same time, he applies the ritual principle of sacrifice. The participants of the happening then “receive” the destroyed telephone (analogous with the torn up god) or even “consume” it via their reconnection in the creative process (analogous with the resurrection). The characters and spectators sew the mobiles on to the travelling assemblage, and they become co-creators of a work of art with a shape that changes from event to event. So through his message ''Requiem for Mobile Telephones'', Kristek achieves what he foretold in his picture ''The Moss Covered Telephone Call''. He experiments with the involvement of the public in events at he{Clarification}} interface between ritual and theatrical and creative art, with the use of random impulses during a collective creative process and with emphasis on the experiencing of the current moment. He attempts to restore lost communication and transform relations in an alienated “digital society”.}} ''Requiem for Mobile Telephones'' belongs to Kristek’s critical assemblages as well as ''Soundproof Aesthetic of Luxuriety'' (1976) that reveals the traps of consume approach and ''In the Prematurely Cloned Age of One Planet'' (2003) that questiones the ethics of current medical science. Lubo Kristek,2007,Requiem für die Mobiltelephone,Wien.jpg|26. April 2007,
Mariahilfer Straße, Vienna Lubo Kristek,2007,Requiem fur Mobiltelephone,Wien.jpg|26. April 2007,
Mariahilfer Straße, Vienna LuboKristek-ThirdEyeOfDistanceCommunication.jpg|10. May 2008,
Neues Stadtmuseum,
Landsberg am Lech Lubo Kristek,2010,Requiem für die Mobiltelephone,Polen.jpg|5. June 2010, City Museum, Sucha Beskidzka Lubo Kristek,2010,Requiem für die Mobiltelephone,Polen(2).jpg|5. June 2010, City Museum, Sucha Beskidzka == Literature == * {{cite book|last=Neunzert|first=Hartfrid|authorlink=|title=Lubo Kristek: Third Eye of Distance Communication|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/888617842|year=2008|location=Landsberg am Lech|publisher=Neues Stadtmuseum}} * Barbora Putová (2013). [http://glyptoteka.cz/images/pdf/kpg-w.pdf ''Kristek’s Glyptothek im Thayatal''] (in German). Brno: VÚKU. {{ISBN|9788090554825}} (Digital ed.), {{ISBN|9788090554818}} (Print ed.). *{{cite book |last=Putová |first=Barbora|year=2018 |title=Kristek Thaya Glyptotheque|url=http://glyptotheque.com |edition=1st Digital|publisher=Research Institute of Communication in Art|access-date=16 August 2018|ISBN=9788090554832}} == External Links == * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8rvhSYcjClM&t=5s Happening at Mariahilfer Straße, Vienna, 2007] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AHdUao6eQE0 Happening in the Neues Stadtmuseum, Landsberg am Lech, 2008] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=s47XPxClIig Happening in the City Museum, Sucha Beskidzka, 2010] == References == [[Category:Performances]]

[[File:Life class at the Royal Female School of Art, 1868.jpg|thumb|right|Life class at the Royal Female School of Art, 1868]] The '''Royal Female School of Art''' was a professional institution for the training of women in fine art. It was founded in 1842, and was known by several names and was housed in various locations in London, including [[Queen Square, London|Queen Square]] and [[Gower Street, London|Gower Street]], before being merged with [[Central School of Art and Design|The Central School of Arts and Crafts]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ucl.ac.uk/bloomsbury-project/institutions/female_school_of_art.htm|title=UCL Bloomsbury Project|website=www.ucl.ac.uk|language=en-UK|access-date=2017-05-15}}</ref>
Notable students and faculty included: * [[Clotilde Graves]] * [[Fanny McIan]], superintendent 1842–1857 * [[Dinah Craik]] * [[Maud Earl]] * [[Elizabeth Thompson|Elizabeth Thompson, Lady Butler]] * [[Helen Allingham]] * [[Anthony Thorold]], president 1861 * [[Evelyn Cheston]]
The Royal Female School of Art Foundation continues to work to support students accessing art education.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://russam-gms.co.uk/trustees/4877/trustees-royal-female-school-of-art-foundation|title=Trustees - Royal Female School of Art Foundation|date=2016-04-29|work=Russam GMS|access-date=2017-05-15|language=en}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Further reading== * [https://russam-gms.co.uk/trustees/4877/trustees-royal-female-school-of-art-foundation/ Royal Female School of Art Foundation] * Chalmers, F. Graeme (1995). "Fanny McIan and London's Female School of Design, 1842-57: "My Lords and Gentlemen, Your Obedient and Humble Servant"?". ''[[Woman's Art Journal]]''. 16 (2): 3–9. [[doi:10.2307/1358568]]

revision.text:
[[File:Chenrezig Sand Mandala.jpg|thumb|[[Chenrezig]] Sand Mandala created and exhibited at the [[House of Commons of the United Kingdom]] on the occasion of the visit of the [[14th Dalai Lama]] on 21 May 2008.]] '''Sand Mandala''' ({{bo|t=དཀྱིལ་འཁོར།|w=dkyil 'khor|thdl=kilkhor}}; {{zh|s=沙坛城|p=Shā Tánchéng}}<nowiki/>) is a [[Tibetan Buddhism|Tibetan Buddhist]] tradition involving the creation and destruction of [[mandalas]] made from coloured [[sand]]. A sand [[mandala]] is ritualistically [[Art destruction|dismantled]] once it has been completed and its accompanying ceremonies and viewing are finished to symbolize the Buddhist doctrinal belief in the transitory nature of material life. {{Tibetan Buddhism}} [[File:Amazing sand mandala.jpg|thumb|right|180px|Sand mandala displaying its materials]]
==Materials and construction== Historically, the mandala was not created with natural, dyed sand, but granules of crushed coloured stone. In modern times, plain white stones are ground down and dyed with opaque inks to achieve the same effect. The monks use a special, extremely dense sand in order to limit interference by things like wind or sneezes. Before laying down the sand, the monks assigned to the project will draw the geometric measurements associated with the mandala. The sand granules are then applied using small tubes, funnels, and scrapers, called [[chak-pur]], until the desired pattern over-top is achieved. Sand mandalas traditionally take several weeks to build due to the large amount of work involved in laying down the sand in such intricate detail. It is common that a team of monks will work together on the project, creating one section of the diagram at a time, working from the centre outwards.
==Themes== The [[Kalachakra]] Mandala for instance, contains 722 deities portrayed within the complex structure and geometry of the mandala itself. Other smaller mandalas, like the one attributed to [[Vajrabhairava]] contain significantly fewer deities and require less geometry, but still take several days to complete. Like all mandalas, these are meant as two-dimensional representations of what is supposed to be a three-dimensional environment. Various buildings have been suggested to be three-dimensional mandalas such as: [[Borobodur]] in Java, Indonesia, and [[the Bayon]] in Siem Reap, Cambodia, although no academic consensus on either has yet been reached.
Many sand mandala contain a specific outer locality which is clearly identified as a [[charnel ground]].
The colours for the painting are usually made with naturally coloured sand, crushed gypsum (white), yellow ochre, red sandstone, charcoal, and a mixture of charcoal and gypsum (blue). Mixing red and black can make brown, red and white make pink. Other colouring agents include corn meal, flower pollen, or powdered roots and bark.
==Ritual destruction== The destruction of a sand mandala is also highly ceremonial. Even the deity syllables are removed in a specific order<ref name=Bryant>{{cite book|last=Bryant|first=Barry|title=Wheel of Time, The: Visual Scripture of Tibetan Buddhism|origyear=1992|year=2003|publisher=Snow Lion Publications|location=Ithaca, NY|isbn=1559391871 |edition=2nd |author2=Yignyen, Tenzin |author3=Samten, Lobsang |author4=Chogyen, Pema Lobsang |author5=Gyaltsen, Dhondup Lobsang |author6=Lhundup, Jamphel |author7=Migyur, Tenzin |author8=Legdan, Tenzin |author9=Gyaltsen, Lobsang |author10=Kirti Tsenshab |author11=Moldow, Deborah |author12=Durgin, Gregory |chapter=X et. seq.}}</ref><!-- ༼༢༢༨།༢༢༩༽ --> along with the rest of the geometry until at last the mandala has been dismantled. The sand is collected in a jar which is then wrapped in silk and transported to a river (or any place with moving water), where it is released back into nature. This symbolizes the ephemerality of life and the world.
==Notable sand mandala artists== *[[Losang Samten]]
==See also== *[[Sandpainting]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== {{commons category|Sand mandalas}} * [http://www.ackland.org/art/exhibitions/buddhistart/construction.htm Image gallery of the construction of a five-and-a-half foot Medicine Buddha sand mandala] * [http://www.liveleak.com/view?i=b42_1275511628 Time-lapse photography of sand mandala]
